column3: s up through two slots in the stitch plate and engages the bottom ply of cloth—will pull the bottom ply under the presser foot and against the pull of the thread. [SEP] The top ply of cloth is carried along by the bottom ply; hence, one ply is stretched more than the other. [SEP] This simple fact of sewing makes it very difficult to automate the process. [SEP] In reality, the two seam lines to be joined are rarely exactly the same length. [SEP] Cutting introduces differences from the top to the bottom of the layers of fabric. column1: In my three decades of teaching university courses in child development, I have
column3: to know thousands of students, many of whom were parents or who became parents soon after completing my class. [SEP] I also served on boards of directors and advisory committees for child-care centers, preschools, elementary schools, and parent organizations. [SEP] And my research continually drew me into classrooms, where for countless hours I observed and recorded preschool and school-age children’s activities, social interactions, and solitary behaviors, in hopes of answering central questions about how they learn. [SEP] As a byproduct of those experiences, parents repeatedly approached me with concerns about how to foster their child’s development in the early years. [SEP] Their fervent questions, at times riddled with doubt and anxiety, revealed that creating optimum learning environme

column1: would prime them for academic success. [SEP] But research eventually documented otherwise—that regimented tutoring not adjusted to the child’s interests and capabilities undermines rather than enhances learning, motivation, and self-control. [SEP] In preschools and kindergartens where much time is spent sitting, listening to teachers, and doing worksheets, children exhibit high levels of stress behaviors, such as wiggling, withdrawal, and talking out. [SEP] They also show a decline in self-conﬁdence and motivation, expressing doubts about their own ability and retreating from challenging problems. [SEP] Furthermore, when followed up during the ﬁrst few years of school, children who spent their kindergarten year in a highly teacher-directed classroom achieve more poorly than do agemates who
column3: from kindergartens emphasizing play and hands-on, small-group projects.28 [SEP] Recall 4-year-old Lydia’s dislike of her academic preschool, described at the beginning of this chapter. [SEP] Lydia’s negative reaction is certainly consistent with research ﬁndings. [SEP] The behaviorist presumption that development can be mechanically engineered by social input, guaranteeing brighter, socially more mature children, is not borne out by the evidence.

column1: As Damon explains, the child-centered philosophy was a major breakthrough when ﬁrst introduced, in that it made parents and teachers aware that children have unique needs and beneﬁt from warmth and encouragement. [SEP] But, Damon contends, modern child-centeredness has been stretched to the point of unrestrained child gratiﬁcation, resulting in a youth culture in which children and adolescents are less engaged, less purposeful, less accomplished academically, and more egoistic and antisocial than in previous generations. [SEP] Damon acknowledges that economic constraints and other family pressures play a part in this youth disaection. [SEP] But he places most blame on how contemporary children are reared. [SEP] Child-centeredness, Damon explains, has be
column3: an excuse for a rudderless parenting and educational culture that makes few demands while fostering in children a stress-free, “feel-good” attitude in which children are told, ”You’re lovable,” “You’re great,” “You’re terriﬁc,” regardless of what they do. [SEP] But because these messages have no basis in meaningful attainment, they are counterproductive. [SEP] Sooner or later, children see through them,

column1: Consider the early attachment bond that builds between caregiver and baby during the ﬁrst year of life. [SEP] By age 6 to 8 months, infants single out their parents and other stable, loving caregivers for expressions of joy and turn to them for comfort when anxious and afraid. [SEP] An overwhelming consensus of research shows that sensitive caregiving—responding to the baby’s cries for physical care and stimulation promptly, consistently, and appropriately—supports the development of a secure attachment relationship.7 [SEP] Securely attached infants actively seek contact with and are easily consoled by their familiar, responsive caregiver. [SEP] Yet such infants are not destined to be
column3: immaturely dependent! [SEP] Rather, by the end of the ﬁrst year, their exploration of the physical world is conﬁdent, persistent, and complex. [SEP] And they are less likely to cry and more likely to use gestures and words to express their desires than are infants whose parents delayed or failed to respond to their calls for help.8 [SEP] Sensitive care builds an interdependent relationship between parent and baby—one in which physical and emotional closeness be

[SEP] Conversations with adults are especially powerful contributors to early childhood language proﬁciency and, in turn, to literacy development.90 [SEP] A strong language foundation is vital for becoming literate because people read to extract meaning. column3: to think in ways that resemble the narrative styles on which the large majority of written texts are based. [SEP] By repeatedly listening to and participating in narrative conversation, children develop mental scripts for the way narratives are typically organized. [SEP] Then, when they start to read, the organization of text material readily makes sense to them, and they extract meaning more easily. [SEP] Indeed, Hannah’s tale suggests that young children denied these supports can still proﬁt from them later, if such supports are available and they have the fortitude to capitalize on them. [SEP] But not all young people are as fortunate as Hannah. [SEP] Some remain profoundly impaired by inadequate adult investment in their childhoods. [SEP] And even those who fare reasonably well may carry with them inner wounds—a sense of emptiness and regret at having missed self-deﬁning, conﬁdence-inducing early experiences that cannot, in the ﬁnal analysis, be recaptured. [SEP] In the course of this chapter, I have had much to say about just how parents and teachers can capitalize on children’s natural propensities. [SEP] Vygotsky’s concept of the “zone” clariﬁes for us the meaning of true “quality time.” [SEP] What must we do to keep young children in the “zone,” motivated, involved, and ever advancing to new heights? [SEP] Here is a brief recap of the communicative principles we have considered: •Forge an adult–child relationship based on shared understanding, or intersubjectivity—one in which the adult strives to “connect” with the child by “stretching down” to his or her point of view, thereby helping the child “stretch up” to the adult’s more mature perspec

[SEP] When adult–child relationships are sympathetic and caring, children want to acquire skills and behave in ways that preserve those gratifying ties. [SEP] They are also more willing to work toward goals that are rational and reasonable. [SEP] Authoritative parenting, which combines the motivating power of warmth with the guidance inherent in scaolding, predicts many aspects of children’s competence. [SEP] •Engage children in narrative conversation about personal experiences, using an elaborative conversational style that poses many varied questions and that expands on the child’s statements. [SEP] Through narrative, children build an autobiographical self permeated with cultural beliefs and values;
column3: to understand that people have rich mental lives and may view the same events dierently; and acquire negotiation strategies for resolving disputes and getting along with others. [SEP] Narrative conversation also fosters language development and emergent literacy, which greatly ease the task of learning to read and write when children get to school. [SEP] Through dialogues with children, adults play a formative role in the development of children’s self-conceptions, sensitivity to others, cognition, academic knowledge, morality, social skills, and capacity to use language to gain control over thought and behavior. What are you doing?’”28 Furthermore, the language skills required to express different points of view, resolve disagreements, and persuade peers to collaborate so play can continue are complex and often subtle. [SEP] Instead, adults often resort to directive strategies, in which they tell children exactly what to say and do and therefore solve the problem for them, as in, “Don’t grab. Ask for a turn!” or “Wait until Sandra is ﬁnished.”77 These techniques are appropriate for children who lack social skills and therefore, at least initially, beneﬁt from clear direction. [SEP] But adults need to modify these strategies to suit children’s play maturity, providing assistance tailored to the child’s “zone.” [SEP] Sticking with directive interventions does not prompt children to
column3: up with effective solutions to conﬂict as it arises—strategies that work because they take into account both the child’s and the playmate’s desires. [SEP] At times, the adult might model a social skill or give the child examples of strategies, as in, “You could ask Paul, ‘Would you let me try it for a while?’ or you could say, ‘May we share it?’” At other times, the adult might encourage the child to generate possible strategies: “What could you do to get Mary and Andrea to let you play, too?” [SEP] In each instance, parents and teachers select the level of support that best matches the child’s current social capacities and then pull back as the child acquires new social problem-solving skills.

[SEP] The best approach is to respond to their questions with simple, direct answers. column1: Most children build up to a tantrum gradually. [SEP] Parents can tell it’s in the offing, and sometimes they can distract the child before it reaches a peak. [SEP] For example, if the child is about to “blow” while you’re out shopping, try involving the child in the shopping experience—pointing out things of interest to the child; asking the child to help you select and carry purchases; and reminding the child that after the shopping is ﬁnished, you are going to do something the child enjoys. [SEP] When parents interrupt a tantrum on the rise by redirecting the child’s attention, they provide strategies children can use on their own to regulate emotion. [SEP] If parents always wait to intervene after the child has be
column3: intensely distressed, it’s harder not only for the parent to calm the child but for the child to learn to calm down. [SEP] And once the child regains emotional control, reassuring the child of parental love with hugs and comforting words restores the parent–child relationship and strengthens the child’s sense of security. [SEP] Make-believe play is an effective context in which preschoolers can practice what to do when frustrated. [SEP] Parent and child can take turns acting out the “parent” and “child” roles. column1: blings, and parental anger escalates. [SEP] The elementary school years are a time when sibling conﬂict can increase. [SEP] As children get feedback about how well they are doing in school and in other activities (such as sports and music lessons), parents may compare their accomplishments, especially when siblings are close in age and the same gender. [SEP] The child who feels less valued is likely to resent a sibling whom parents seem to prefer. [SEP] Therefore, when praising one child, parents should try not to diminish the merits of another. [SEP] If a sibling expresses jealousy, parents can remind the envious child of an admirable personal trait or a recent commendable performance. [SEP] But be careful not to give empty praise (not based on real accomplishment), which children quickly
column3: to mistrust. [SEP] It may fuel jealousy of a sibling, whom the child concludes parents really appreciate. [SEP] In sum, parents can foster positive sibling ties through expressing warmth and affection, stressing each child’s positive qualities and achievements, and refraining from making comparisons. [SEP] When sibling relationships are friendly and sympathetic, they bring many beneﬁts, including gratifying companionship, emotional support, and assistance with everyday tasks.

[SEP] By collaborating with the child on a challenging task, the adult assesses what the child can already do and what the child is ready to learn, providing a support system for mastery. [SEP] The metaphor of a scaffold, discussed in Chapter 2, is an excellent guide for how to help your child with homework. [SEP] Scaffolding involves varying your assistance to ﬁt the child’s changing competence. [SEP] When the child says, “I don’t understand,” you can adjust the task, breaking it into smaller parts. [SEP] You can also provide prompts, hints, and explanations, increasing the amount and directiveness of your guidance until the child makes progress. [SEP] As you do so, you can assist the child in analyzing why certain problem-solving approaches work and others do not, encouraging her to
column3: up with ideas for surmounting difficulties. [SEP] As she starts to apply the strategies derived from your dialogue, you can reduce the intensity of your intervention, letting her take over responsibility for the task. [SEP] Too often, parents imagine that their child’s classmates can do the homework assignment independently. [SEP] After all, they say to themselves, why would the teacher have assigned it if this weren’t so? [SEP] This pattern of reasoning leads parents down a counterproductive path. [SEP] “What’s wrong with my child?” they say to themselves. [SEP] “She should be able to do the assignment, just like everyone else!” [SEP] But recall that children of the same age differ widely in their “zones.” [SEP] And rooted in the very idea of the “zone” is that learning requires teaching!

[SEP] Alabados were sung as ritual prayers in homes, at dawn, noon, and at nightfall, and they were almost always sung at funeral processions. [SEP] Their melodies are fusions of indigenous music and medieval chants. [SEP] Stories of Mexican California narrate the singing of alabados first thing in the morning by a family, each member in his/her own room, but all together at the same time. [SEP] Like the décima (ten-line poetic song) and the romance (four-line song), alabados were introduced into the New World by the Franciscan padres, who taught them to the Indian people as they were teaching them the Bible and converting them to Christianity. column3: to mean any religious hymn sung at wakes or religious ceremonies. [SEP] Many are very old and the authors unknown, although a few collected in southern Colorado were written by a local singer in the 1940s. [SEP] Folklorists of the 1930s and 1940s were still able to collect some of these ancient hymns from elderly people who learned them from their parents in the nineteenth century. [SEP] Juan Rael published one of the first essays on the alabado in 1950, and a recent researcher, William Gonzalez of the University of Utah, calls them “some of the saddest music” (Ingalls B11). column3: to mean a taco made of a wheat flour tortilla instead of a corn tortilla, filled with meat, rice, frijoles (beans), and chile, then folded and rolled up. [SEP] There are several theories about the origins of the name burrito, and there may be some truth to all of them. [SEP] One theory is that when flour tortillas became available in northern Mexico, tacos de frijoles, or bean burritos, were easy to carry in the saddle-bags of the vaqueros (cowboys), so for this reason they came to be called burritos as though they were the sidekicks of the vaquero’s horse. [SEP] Tacos made from corn tortillas are much older; they have been around since the epoch of the Aztecs. [SEP] Low riders have commonly been associated with cholos (1990s urban youth) and gangs, but traditionally Chicanos seriously involved in low riding and customizing low-rider cars are not involved in gangs, and low-rider clubs actually present an alternative to gang involvement. [SEP] Chicano social scientists have authored studies about machismo, noting that it is a stereotype often used against Chicanos to blame them for their underclass social position in American society. [SEP] Macho literally means “male,” and machismo is the concept of “maleness,” but in American culture it has
column3: to mean an exaggerated masculinity. [SEP] A masculinity associated with violence, self-centeredness, chauvinism, or alcoholism is not a macho concept recognized by most Chicanos. [SEP] For Chicanos, un hombre macho is a man who symbolizes dignity, takes care of his family, has respect for all women, especially his mother, and possesses a strong sense of self-identity and character. column1: s, it portrays the betrayal of Montezuma by the Spaniards, and the acceptance of Christianity by Montezuma. [SEP] Its Iberian origins lie in the conflict between the Christians and Moors. [SEP] The Danza de los Matachines is probably the only ritual dance that is danced by both Hispanic and Native American communities in New Mexico. [SEP] The word matachines can translate to mean “clowning” or “trickery,” but can also mean “puppet player,” “jester,” and “buffoon.” [SEP] Matachines refers to the men who dance as a group; the group is composed usually of twelve men, but can have from ten to fourteen. [SEP] In sixteenth-century Europe a matachin was a masked dancer, an entertainer who danced with a sword. [SEP] It is likely that the Moors transplanted the dance to Europe and that matachin may
column3: from the Arabic word mutawajjihin, meaning “to assume a mask.” [SEP] There are many eighteenth- and nineteenth-century literary references to a matachine sword dance, indicating that such a dance was performed in Europe. [SEP] Similar to the dance-drama of Los Moros y Cristianos, the dance of Los Matachines was taught to the subjugated Indians by the Spanish missionaries as a custom to celebrate on Christian feast days but also as a means of converting them to Catholicism. [SEP] Flavia Waters Champe’s interpretation is that the dance was brought to New Mexico by Spanish and Mexican settlers who came with De Vargas at the time of the second conquest in 1692.

[SEP] It is unknown how the word mica originated as a name for the green card. [SEP] In Spanish a mica is a female monkey, but it is used for a woman who flirts with men or a coquette. column1: La Migra (Immigration Officials) La migra is an abbreviated and slang term for the Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS) and the Border Patrol. [SEP] The phrase “hay viene la migra!” has been cried out in fear for many generations in Mexicano and Chicano communities and in the workplaces where they are employed. [SEP] Raids by la migra are commonplace and have been depicted in films, novels, jokes, and verbal narratives for many years. [SEP] Migra is short for the Spanish word immigración, and has be
column3: an important and viable character in the vocabulary and culture of Chicanos and Mexicanos alike. [SEP] Cartoons and jokes often depict la migra officials as overweight policemen who chase down innocent women and children. [SEP] In the folk dramas of El Teatro Campesino (the Farmworkers’ Theater), la migra was often characterized as an unscrupulous arrogant patrol officer who accepted bribes from the growers and ordered raids in the agricultural fields to arrest undocumented immigrants the day before payday. [SEP] Starting in the late 1940s and into the present, la migra made raids in the San Joaquin Valley of California, rounding up braceros who had overstayed their contract time allocation. column1: Mojado (Wetback) A translation of the word “wetback,” sometimes spelled moja’o, which literally simply means “wet.” [SEP] It is a pejorative expression, although it is sometimes used by Mexican people to describe themselves and their experience of illegally crossing the Rio Grande to
column3: to the United States. [SEP] Also it is a designation used against all Chicanos, with the same prejudicial meaning as “greaser” or “spic.” [SEP] Some Chicanos use the term to refer to recent Mexican immigrants and also to differentiate themselves from undocumented immigrants. [SEP] Among teenage Chicanos the word mojado is translated to English and illegal Mexicans are often just called “wets.” [SEP] Descriptions of the wetback experience have been chronicled and narrated in corridos (ballads) and novels. [SEP] In Mexico, the term sometimes used is espaldas mojadas, a literal translation for the word wetback. column3: from the word penitenciaria, or “penitentiary.” [SEP] Other common words for prison are bote, meaning “can,” and corre, which is short for “correctional institution,” referring specifically to one in Texas. column3: to be used as an in-group name for Mexican and Chicano people. [SEP] Translated as “the people,” it is recognized as meaning all mixed-race Spanish and Indian people, known as mestizos. [SEP] The term encompasses all Latinos (Latin Americans) who are descendents of the Spanish and Indian encounter. [SEP] Publishing after the Mexican Revolution, Vasconcelos envisioned the successful future of Mexico to lie in the strong bonds of its mixed-race population. [SEP] Before the Revolution, in the nineteenth century, Mexicans looked toward a European identity, and most of the upper classes considered themselves white Europeans. [SEP] After being painted and filled with flowers and plants, these plant containers do not even resemble their original form. [SEP] Recycled tire planters can line a driveway or establish the boundaries of a large yard. [SEP] The practice of reusing objects that have lost their original purpose, such as kitchen pitchers and pots, is a means of keeping something familiar, something associated with a memory, alive and finding a new use for it. [SEP] This practice probably originates from poverty, but the historical result has been that it creates its own aesthetic in adding adornment to one’s home and life. [SEP] These “yardscapes,” as they’ve
column3: to be called, are composed of bits and pieces of one’s personal life and as such can add visual charm and historical value to a home. [SEP] A family’s religious and cultural values, as well as the special identity of being Mexican American, can be found in yardas. [SEP] See also Folk Art; Nichos; Yard Shrines

[SEP] The word Zozobra translates to “gloom” or “worry” or “anguished.” [SEP] The Zozobra is ritualistically burned at the beginning of the fiesta, which symbolizes the end of destructiveness, gloom, and worry, setting the tone for a successful fiesta. column3: “dull and commercialized.” [SEP] Throughout the years the image of Zozobra changed from a simple twenty-foot puppet to the elaborate forty-foot figure with animated eyes, arms, and mouth that he is today. [SEP] In 1969 Shuster turned over the responsibility and copyright of Zozobra to the Kiwanis Club of Santa Fe. column1: n his agenda was revamping the legal system. [SEP] In 1804, he charged a group of lawyers with the task of drafting a new civil code in language accessible to ordinary people. [SEP] The committee produced the elegant Code civil, now a mainstay of French culture and a model for civil codification all over the world. [SEP] The language is so refined that the novelist Henri Stendhal reportedly reviewed the style of ten code provisions every night before retiring. [SEP] Today, when the Francophones in Quebec preach the distinctiveness of their culture, they never fail to mention their Code civil, modeled after Napoleon’s effort to use the law as the means of restoring civilized order to France. [SEP] The Code civil has proved to be remarkably durable in French culture. [SEP] Constitutions have
column3: and gone and the French have endured recurrent changes of regime, including communes, dictatorships, and five distinct republics. [SEP] Yet, through all this, the civil code has survived. [SEP] It is the cultural monument that unites the French across history. [SEP] In its substantive content, the Code civil is strongly identified with the achievements of the 1789 Revolution against the ancien regime. [SEP] The code sweeps away the vestiges of feudal influence in the law of property and in the law of evidence and proclaims a liberal legal order. [SEP] The end of feudalism in the law of property meant that a single concept of ownership would replace the ancient system of embedded estates. [SEP] I suggest that we proceed and listen, sentence by sentence, phrase by phrase, to these words heard so often. [SEP] The first sentence states the heart of the matter and sums up the past, present, and future of the American commitment. [SEP] Four score and seven years ago our fathers brought forth on this continent a new nation, conceived in liberty and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal. [SEP] Four score and seven years ago. [SEP] . . By 1863, a historical consciousness had taken hold in American thinking. Rooting ourselves in the past stands in sharp contrast to the preamble of the 1787 Constitution, which begins simply, without setting the context: “We the people of the United States, in order to form a more perfect Union. . . .” [SEP] There is no reference in the 1787 document to the first settlement dating back some 160 years, no sense that the new country was the outgrowth of an English-speaking culture across the seas. [SEP] The substitution of the Americans for the covenanted Jews—however sacrilegious the idea may sound—landed in the New World with the Puritans and became a standard item of Protestant theology. [SEP] Thus, we can understand Lincoln referring at Trenton to the Americans as “His [God’s] almost chosen people.”15

[SEP] The principle of national self-determination, urged so adamantly in the twentieth century, derives from the same source: every nation is entitled to preserve its own culture, cultivate its language, and express itself as a subject of the international community. [SEP] International law is based on the idea that nations, anchored in the form of states, enter into legal relationships. [SEP] The states in which nations are embodied enjoy legal personalities. [SEP] It is no wonder, therefore, that the Declaration of Independence would assert that the American people were equally entitled, with all other nations, to determine their form of government. [SEP] These two senses of the famous “all men are created equal” capture the ambiguous quality of the American revolt against the British. [SEP] It was both a revolutionary and an anticolonial war of independence. [SEP] The revolutionary spirit was captured in the categorical rejection of monarchy. [SEP] The anticolonial thrust appears in the assertion of the Americans’ equal claim to rule by “consent of the governed.”

[SEP] They are created equal and remain equal in the eyes of their Creator. [SEP] Of course, many framers of the Declaration were slave owners and most, if not all of them, were patriarchal heads of households. [SEP] Legal texts often bear one meaning on their surface and a higher meaning that requires faith and personal investment beyond the surface meaning. [SEP] A good example is the commandment in the Decalogue prohibiting homicide. [SEP] Allow me a short digression on the commandment against killing to illustrate the phenomenon of a text that carries one meaning on its surface and a more radical meaning beneath.

column1: Gettysburg forged a link between the nation and egalitarian thinking that we sometimes forget. [SEP] The connection between the limited nation and unbounded equality has paradoxical overtones. [SEP] The nation is dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal. [SEP] The thrust toward equality has universalist implications. [SEP] Neither Lincoln in 1863 nor the founders in 1776 argued that only “Americans” were created equal. [SEP] The claim was that all people—in principle, all human beings on the planet—are born with equal dignity. [SEP] Yet, this universalistic thinking thins our commitment to equality to a point of fragility. [SEP] Equality flourishes in an environment of mutual sympathy and reciprocal identification. [SEP] The love for each and the needs of each
column3: to the fore in the affective bonds of family, friendship, tribe, and, by extension, in the reciprocal attachments of nationhood. [SEP] The limited political sphere of the nation facilitates the recognition of others as human beings sharing a common history. [SEP] If blacks and whites, Northerners and Southerners, eventually men and women, could respect each other as Americans participating in the same national drama, they would lay a foundation for affirming their mutual equality. [SEP] They need not be brothers and not exactly friends, but they could at last recognize each other as compatriots with a common language, a single history, and a shared future. [SEP] The local tourist office can arrange tours of wineries and tastings (Adega de Cooperativa de Lagoa; Tel. 282/342 181; 24 hours in advance). [SEP] New golf courses are being built in the area, but there’s little else to detain visitors. [SEP] From Lagoa, turn south about 5 km (3 miles) to the charming resort of Carvoeiro, an archetypal small Barlavento resort. [SEP] The beach is about the size of a tablecloth compared with some of the expanses to the east. [SEP] A single road runs down through a pretty valley until it

column1: The architectural highlight of the village is the beautiful 16th-century Igreja Matriz, entered through a classic Manueline portal. [SEP] The church keeper will enthusiastically point out the many elaborate chapels and the rare 16th-century Sevillana azulejos. [SEP] The rest of Alte is the Algarve of postcards — white-washed houses along narrow streets, colorful windows, filigreed chimney pots, and red-tiled roofs. [SEP] And while their character may at first seem uniform, you won’t see two houses the same. [SEP] Follow the stream upriver and you
column3: to the popular Pequena Fonte (Little Fountain) springs, where a restaurant and occasional folk dancing draw visitors. [SEP] The setting is delightful and a perfect spot for a picnic. [SEP] If you continue east on N-124, you’ll pass rolling hills and

[SEP] Every square inch of the Baroque, 15th-century church — its walls, vaulted ceiling, and cupola — is covered with hand-painted, blue-and-white ceramic tiles. [SEP] Most date from the early 18th century and depict biblical scenes detailing the life of St. Lawrence, born across the border in Huesca, Spain. [SEP] The only element of the church not blue-and-white is the carved, gilded altar. [SEP] The ensemble is a stunning sight, not to be missed. [SEP] Loulé, north of Almancil, is a regional produce center with a large Saturday market, known for its leather, lace, and copper goods. [SEP] Loulé is a prosperous town with an ambitious, modern boulevard complete with outdoor cafés that are jam-packed on market day. [SEP] Coach parties
column3: from far and wide to shop at the colorful, bustling market. [SEP] There are actually two markets. [SEP] Fresh produce, including fish, is sold in a mock-Moorish hall, while a “gypsy market” is held towards the opposite end of the boulevard. [SEP] Just below the permanent market halls, on the main Praça da República, you’ll find a well-preserved section of the medieval castle walls (which were much damaged by the 1755 earthquake). [SEP] The ramparts afford excellent views from the town, and set into the castle remains is a modest local museum. [SEP] Also worth visiting are the Igreja Matriz (São Clemente), a 13th-century Gothic church with 18th-century azulejo tiles; the Convento da Graça, with a terrific Manueline portal; and Ermida de Nossa Senhora da Conceição, a small church prized for i

column1: The Sotavento Coast Heading east from the provincial capital of Faro, the first settlement of any size you will
column3: to is the colorful fishing town of Olhão. [SEP] A working port, it has made few concessions to tourism and is full of character. [SEP] Olhão has often been described as the “little white Cubist town of the Algarve,” its architecture likened to that of North African towns. [SEP] That may have been the case some years ago, but modern development has strongly interfered with its once distinctive appearance. [SEP] You can judge for yourself by ascending the bell tower of the parish church (which also goes by the name of Nossa Senhora do Rosário), which you will find by winding your way through the narrow streets back to the Praça da Restauração (you may have to ask for access to the tower in the sacristy). [SEP] Founded by King Dom Pedro II in 1698, the church has an impressive, scroll-decorate

column1: East Toward Spain After the salty flavor of Olhão and the rural serenity of Moncarapacho, the aristocratic bearings of Tavira, one of the true gems of the Algarve, may
column3: as something of a surprise. [SEP] One of the region’s most historic cities, its Moorish, Reconquista, and Renaissance roots are clearly visible. [SEP] In the 1500s, Tavira had the largest population on the Algarve. [SEP] This tuna-fishing port and self-assured town of historic churches, imposing classical-style mansions, and riverfront gardens probably dates back as far as the Phoenicians or the Carthaginians. [SEP] In fact, its seven-arched stone bridge of Roman origin is still in use.

column1: At ground level, seedy or amusing ( depending on your point of view) shops sell sex wares, attracting customers from all walks of life; but don’t get too distracted, else you’ll miss the rows of dainty gables, quirky wall plaques, and window boxes brimming with flowers, which give the whole area a cheery feel. [SEP] Don’t be surprised to find offices, shops, and restaurants living side by side with the brothels here — it’s all part of Amsterdam life. [SEP] At night the streets
column3: alive with bars, clubs, and adult shows. [SEP] It is one of liveliest parts of the city after dark. [SEP] Just make sure that you stay on the busier and well-lit thoroughfares as you make your way back to your hotel. [SEP] You will find several historical gems as you wander Walletjes. [SEP] One of the narrow houses on Oudezijds Voorburgwal — number 40 — has a wonderful secret to share. [SEP] Museum Amstrelkring was a merchant’s house bought by Catholic Jan Hartman in 1661. [SEP] Following the Alteration in 1578 Catholics were not permitted to practice their religion, and Hartman — along with a number of other wealthy Catholics of the time — had a secret chapel built, where his family and friends could worship. [SEP] Although they were common at the time, this is now the only secret chapel l

[SEP] The museum can be a confusing maze of connecting rooms — additions were completed in 1898 and 1919 — so it pays to sit down for a few minutes to study the very comprehensive map, which accompanies your ticket. [SEP] A multimedia interactive study area also allows you to review the vast collection on a screen, pinpoint works which you want to see, and print out further details of each piece. [SEP] The center, called ARIA (Amsterdam Rijksmuseum InterActief), is located in room 225, behind the Night Watch room. [SEP] You can also take advantage of an audio CD tour to give you background detail as you explore. [SEP] The collection is varied but most visitors

[SEP] Among the collection are 20 works by Rembrandt, including The Nightwatch, properly entitled The Company of Captain Frans Banning Cocq and Lieutenant Willem van Ruytenburch. [SEP] The work, which was commissioned by the company for its barracks, is remarkable for its lack of formality and very different from the accepted style of the day. [SEP] Johannes Vermeer (1632–1675) is also well-represented, and his effective use of light can be clearly seen in The Kitchen Maid, painted in 1660, which is one of the gallery’s best-loved pieces. column1: A Brief History In ancient Greek mythology Athens is named following a contest between Athena, goddess of wisdom, and Poseidon, god of the sea. [SEP] Both had their eye on the prize real estate, so it was agreed that whoever could
column3: up with the more useful gift for mortals would win. [SEP] The half-human, half-serpent king of Athens, Cecrops, acted as arbiter. [SEP] First came Poseidon, who struck the rock of the Acropolis with his mighty trident and brought salt water gushing forth. [SEP] Then it was Athena’s turn. [SEP] As she struck the rock an olive tree appeared, which proved more useful and valuable. [SEP] Thus she acquired the position of the city’s special protector.

column1: For almost 50 years after Platae, peace reigned at home, and the victorious city-state entered its most brilliant era. [SEP] Athens was instrumental in bringing the disparate Aegean and mainland communities together, creating a “league of nations”, known as the Delian League. [SEP] The headquarters of the League was originally on the island of Delos but it was moved to Athens itself in 454 b.c. The resources of the treasury of the Delian League were used — among other things — to build the Parthenon and other monuments that still adorn the Acropolis today. [SEP] The moving power behind this unrivaled time of greatness, which has
column3: to be known as the Golden Age, was Pericles. [SEP] This liberal-inclined aristocrat was, in effect, the supreme ruler of Athens and its empire for 30 years until his death in 429 b.c. Great works of art, literature, science, and philosophy were produced by what Pericles referred to as the “school of Hellas.” [SEP] Major names of the time included the dramatists Euripides and Sophocles, the historian Herodotus, the philosopher Socrates, and the brilliant scientists Zeno and Anaxagoras. [SEP] The first literary salon in history was presided over by Aspasia, Pericles’ mistress, a remarkable woman of intelligence and spirit.

column1: Athenians understand this. [SEP] They are not daunted or downhearted by their surroundings, they enjoy their city, revelling in the opportunities it gives them. [SEP] Every district has its own small squares with cafés, where people gather for a drink or meal — and Athenians love to eat out. [SEP] You’ll be surprised at the wealth of good restaurants offering international cuisine, and how much post-modernist décor influences interior design in the smarter districts. [SEP] Of course the Greek taverna hasn’t be
column3: extinct. [SEP] Locals as much as visitors enjoy the fresh and delicious cuisine that’s been served in Greece for centuries. [SEP] Greek theater is thriving at new auditoria such as the Megaron complex, or at the open-air theaters on Lycabettus Hill. [SEP] The annual Athens Festival has a full program of music, dance, and poetry with a rich historical legacy. [SEP] Sports are still avidly followed, though today it’s more likely to be football, not a discus throw, that excites the emotions. [SEP] Powerboat racing out on the waters of the Saronic Gulf also raises the adrenalin of the wealthy. [SEP] Tradition still plays an important part in daily life here. [SEP] The family forms the backbone of Greek society and filial ties are strong. [SEP] Children play safely in the streets with grandma ke

column1: Athens
column3: s alive after dark with a range of activities to fill your diary. [SEP] However, you’ll probably need to alter your normal routine to enjoy it as the locals do. [SEP] Theater performances are followed by a late leisurely dinner, often after 11pm, and if you intend to head out to a nightclub, don’t expect to start until around midnight. [SEP] Even if you only want to sample the delights of Greek tavernas and perhaps stroll around Plaka, the real atmosphere starts after 9pm when Greek families

column1: Spectator Sports Football (soccer): Football is a national obsession for the Greeks and Athens’ teams (Panathanaikos and AEK Athens) feature prominently in domestic and European competitions. [SEP] The season runs from September to May. [SEP] Panathanaikos Football Stadium is located at Kifissia, a northern suburb — this will be the major stadium for the 2004 Olympic Games, which will be held in the city. [SEP] Ask your hotel if it is possible to get tickets as these are difficult to
column3: by. [SEP] Horseracing: Athens Race course can be found at the bottom of Syngrou Avenue where racing takes place on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Saturdays. [SEP] Plans have been drawn up to redevelop the course as part of the Athens 2004 Olympic program, so make enquiries with your hotel or the EOT before making the journey out to the course.

column1: Statuary: If you want a little piece of ancient Greece then you’ll certainly be able to find it. [SEP] It will be a reproduction of course — but still you can own your own copy of Zeus, Poseidon, or Athena herself, small enough to grace a table or large enough to decorate a garden. [SEP] Plaques depicting ancient friezes, or masks to hang on walls are also extremely popular, as are Mycenaean helmets. [SEP] If classical statuary is too ornate for your taste, you can also find copies of the minimalist Mycenaean statues found at the Goulandris Museum. [SEP] The National Archaeological Museum also has a wide range of copies of its artifacts. [SEP] Each
column3: s with a certificate of authentication. [SEP] Leatherware: Local craftsmen have always worked goat and cow hides and the industry continues today. [SEP] Footwear, bags, and clothing

column1: Leatherware: Local craftsmen have always worked goat and cow hides and the industry continues today. [SEP] Footwear, bags, and clothing
column3: in a range of styles, though quality is generally more rustic and bohemian than similar items produced in Italy or France. [SEP] Carpets and needlepoint: Ottoman craftsmen left behind a legacy in both the use and production of fine carpets — look for hand-knotted ornate patterns in wool or silk which

Kritikos Boy and Blond-haired Boy — two sculptures carved in the “severe” style fashionable around 480 b.c. are displayed in room 6. [SEP] Panels from the Ionic frieze that decorated the Parthenon are in room 8, and the original Caryatids can be found in room 9. [SEP] When you have explored the architectural delights of the Acropolis, take time to enjoy the views from its walls. [SEP] Sections of the stone defences date back to Mycenaean times, though the majority were constructed during the first millennium and were reinforced by the Turks. [SEP] From the north you can take in the other major archaeological sites and the district of Plaka directly below. [SEP] From the east the verdant slopes of Mount Lycabettus
column3: into view, with the smart district of Kolonaki on its lower slopes. [SEP] South leads the eye towards the coast and the islands of the Saronic Gulf. [SEP] As you leave the site via the smooth stone path through the Propylaia you’ll pass the Monument of Agrippa. [SEP] Originally erected with a single chariot to commemorate victory in the Panathenaic Games, a second chariot group including Marcus Agrippa was added in 27 b.c. You’ll leave through the Beulé Gate, a remaining part of the Roman defensive system.

column1: To the west of the Acropolis stands another small range of hills now cut by footpaths and covered in trees offering cooling shade in the heat of summer. [SEP] This area, reached by crossing Odós Rovertou Gali and walking up behind the Dionysus restaurant, offers splendid views across to the Acropolis (it’s the best place for afternoon overviews), and the Sound and Light Show auditorium is located here for this reason. [SEP] Several archaeological sites can be seen and the area is much less crowded than the Acropolis itself. [SEP] You’ll also see the 16th century church, Ayios Dimítrios Loumbardhi, nestling under the woodland canopy. [SEP] In the northeastern area, you’ll
column3: to the Hill of the Pnyx, meeting place of the Assembly of Athens. [SEP] Loosely translated, pnyx means “crowded or tightly packed place,” and in ancient times this was a highly populated area. [SEP] You’ll see the outlines of walls, including the defensive Themistoklean Wall, between the bushes or under the turf as you stroll. [SEP] The Pnyx meeting place can be found below the summit on the northeastern side of the hill. [SEP] When democracy was established at the end of the sixth century b.c. the debating chamber moved from the Agora to this structure and it was here that the great statesmen of Greece made their speeches at the rostrum. [SEP] Seats were provided for the 5,000 citizens of the city needed for a decision-making quorum, who would listen to the arguments of Pericles and Themis

column1: quaysides in the Main Harbor cater to hundreds of ferries large and small, and you’ll see fleets of large container ships laying anchor offshore. [SEP] Walking south along the quaysides brings you to a small shady square with the Cathedral of Agia Triada on its northern flank. [SEP] Take this street (Dimokratias) to the Town Hall and visit the lively daily market that takes place in the surrounding streets. [SEP] Take a right down Lampraki to reach the pretty harbor of Zea. [SEP] This is one of the marinas used for pleasure craft, and where Athenians — rich and not so rich — moor their boats. [SEP] These range from simple rowing boats of just a few feet in length to hundred-foot ocean-going vessels. [SEP] A wide promenade  — Akti Moutsopoulou — frames the bay and this is where local people
column3: to stroll in the evenings and on weekends —  you can sit at a portside café and watch the world go by. [SEP] North from Zea harbor is another pretty harbor, Mikrolimani (Small Harbor) or Tourkolimani, where you’ll find the fishing fleet and some good fish tavernas. [SEP] Or head south towards the main historical attractions of Piraeus.

column1: Paintings and art work with scenes of everyday life also make beautiful mementos. [SEP] The work of a number of artists, including Alton Lowe and Eddie Minnis, is becoming very collectable and prices can be high. [SEP] On the other end of the scale, street art, including things like driftwood paintings, can be fun and much more affordable. [SEP] Wood carvings are made from a variety of native trees. [SEP] Some of the best are made from the lignum vitae, the Bahamian national tree, and from the wild tamarind. [SEP] The carvings
column3: in a bewildering variety, though animal and fish motifs seem to predominate. [SEP] Always check a piece thoroughly before you buy as they are vary in quality. [SEP] Don’t buy wood if it looks green — this usually means the wood has not been allowed to season, and it may split as it dries. [SEP] Seashells and sponges can be found in every market and souvenir shop in the Bahamas. [SEP] They make beautiful, natural souvenirs, but some may

column1: paradise for sailors. [SEP] Safe harbors with superb facilities, cozy coves for a night alone, and the possibility of making short hops to a different port every night allow sailors to experience all the different atmospheres of the various islands. [SEP] On many of the islands, renting a boat is as easy as renting a car is in other destinations — especially on the more populated Out Islands. [SEP] Rentals can vary from small runabouts that will get you around the harbor and the coastal shallows to large sailing yachts and motor launches for inter-island expeditions. [SEP] Rates vary enormously. [SEP] To make more of a stay in the Abacos or Exumas, where there are many outlaying cays, you can rent a 18-ft (51⁄2-m) boat with small outboard motor for around $80 per day. [SEP] Larger vessels
column3: with a crew and/or guide; if you sail your own boat, you can take advantage of the services of a local guide to take you to fishing, snorkeling, or dive sites. [SEP] The Abacos are most popular spot for sailing, primarily because of the many sheltered harbors and the many islands and cays that you can reach without having to go outside of the reefs and into ocean waters. [SEP] If you want to get out and see a lot of boats without doing any sailing, head to the Bahamas during the Regattas, when boats crowd the harbors and the little towns are full of yachtsmen. [SEP] Listen to the stories of heroic deeds in the bars and enjoy the wonderful views of masts filling the skies.

column1: alk. [SEP] For many years this has been the showcase for Bahamian handicrafts. [SEP] Straw goods, including baskets and mats, are favorite souvenirs; each island produces straw goods in its own style and patterns. [SEP] Bestsellers are hats, dolls, bags, and baskets. [SEP] There is some exquisite work to be found, but be aware that with a decline in basket-making throughout the Bahamas, an increasing number of articles are imported from the Far East; most of these are at the cheaper end of the scale. [SEP] The ubiquitous modern souvenir, the T-shirt, is also available, with an almost limitless number of pictures, patterns, and slogans. [SEP] The ladies who run the stalls are easy-going and seem to have limitless enthusiasm for the next sale. [SEP] You’ll hear numerous calls of “Hey, honey,
column3: look for something nice here.” [SEP] The straw market fronts onto Bay Street, one of the leading duty-free shopping capitals of the world. [SEP] Only a few years ago this street was the domain of the Bay Street Boys, a small group of men who controlled all economic activity in the Bahamas; now Bay Street seduces visitors with huge sparkling gems, hundreds of ounces of gold, and the smell of a thousand designer fragrances. [SEP] The façades of the pretty 18th-century shops hide modern air-conditioned shopping palaces piled high with luxury goods.

[SEP] Its recent history is fascinating: In the 1930s it was owned by Swedish millionaire Axel Wenner-Gren, an arms manufacturer who was found to be a Nazi sympathizer. [SEP] He sold the island to Huntingdon Hartford, who changed the name from Hog to Paradise and created a beautiful private retreat, now the Ocean Club Hotel. [SEP] Later gangster Per Lansky began the process that transformed the island from a private sanctuary with magnificent homes into a playground for tourists. [SEP] The wonderful beaches, such as Cabbage Beach on the northern coast, were the focus of the development. [SEP] The first hotels began to appear in the 1960s when gambling was a lure to the rich and famous. [SEP] As Paradise Island saw owners Donald Trump and Merv Griffin
column3: and go, it went through a continuing series of developments and re-developments. [SEP] Today Paradise Island may be close to fulfilling the dream of the perfect vacation playground. [SEP] It has many of the essential ingredients needed: fine white-sand beaches, a protected marina, a golf course, a group of fine hotels, and perhaps the biggest adult playground this side of Las Vegas. [SEP] The brainchild of the Sol Group, Atlantis Paradise Island is a new concept in resorts — it’s a huge hotel with an amazing theme park and entertainment village all on one site. [SEP] The resort takes its name, and inspiration, from the lost city of Atlantis, said by some to lie off the coast of Bimini. [SEP] This theme runs throughout the whole resort. column1: rkland. [SEP] Head back to the main coast road and you will find two small cays lying immediately offshore. [SEP] The first is Arawak Cay, home to the local fishing fleet. [SEP] A number of colorful shacks line the approach road where you can buy conch and fried fish, always fresh and always delicious. [SEP] Weekends can be busy with local families. [SEP] Travel through Arawak Cay to reach Silver Cay, where there is a small resort with a pretty beach. [SEP] Here you will find Crystal Cay, site of a marine park where you can take a close look at the undersea world without getting wet. [SEP] A man-made coral reef has been created on the sea bottom and you can watch all the marine activity from an underwater observatory. [SEP] The reef attracts many kinds of aquatic creatures that are free to
column3: and go as they please. [SEP] The observatory looks decidedly futuristic and can be seen quite clearly from the road as you travel along the coast. [SEP] Other activities at Crystal Cay include a sea turtle environment, a touch pool where you can stroke a sting ray or pet a conch, and a snorkel trail, if you want to get into the water yourself. [SEP] A little further west along the coast you will find Cable Beach, the third main center of tourism on New Providence. [SEP] Several luxury hotels line the shore, only 5 minutes by car from central Nassau. [SEP] The Nassau Marriott Resort Hotel attracts many visitors with its casino, stage shows, and restaurants. [SEP] The Cable Beach “strip” is under continual development, and a number of private restaurants have opened recently to provide altern

column1: ive Port Lucaya marina gives the whole resort a very nautical feel. [SEP] A number of large hotels line the Lucayan Beach, their massive façades softened by the hundreds of masts of the yachts moored on the inlet. [SEP] As of late 1999, the casinos and many of the hotels were being given a facelift and three of the larger hotels on the waterfront were being reconfigured into a single complex. [SEP] Port Lucaya Marketplace is the center of all activity for the town. [SEP] During the day the duty-free shops in this Mediterranean-style shopping village tempt shoppers with jewelry, clothing, and perfume; colorful wooden huts house craft stalls selling straw work and carvings. [SEP] As the sun sinks people gather at the marketplace after a day on the beach or sailing offshore. [SEP] The streets
column3: alive as bars and restaurants fill up and bands play live music at the Count Basie Bandstand in a square adjoining the marina. [SEP] On the south side of the marina, accessible from the main beach road, is the Underwater Explorers Society or UNEXSO. [SEP] The oldest diving organization in the Bahamas, UNEXSO provides diving experience sessions and training courses. [SEP] The large square building contains a diving pool and decompression chamber; those with no interest in actually practicing the sport can visit the museum, which charts the development of diving to the modern SCUBA (self-contained underwater breathing apparatus) method developed by Jacques Cousteau in the 1930s. [SEP] There is also a good restaurant on site, the Brass Helmet. [SEP] A short boatride from Port Lucaya takes you

column1: As you head east out of town you’ll soon leave the trappings of modernity behind and find yourself on a good road through acres of Bahamian forest. [SEP] The road crosses a number of canals, and just off the south coast is Petersons Cay, a tiny but beautiful coral cay with a beach — a great spot for a day of swimming, snorkeling, sunbathing, and picnicking. [SEP] After traveling approximately 10 miles on the main road you’ll
column3: to Lucaya National Park (there’s a small parking lot on your left). [SEP] The 40-acre (16-hectare) park sits on both sides of the main road and protects a range of Bahamian ecosystems. [SEP] Inland, trails lead to one of the largest surveyed cave systems in the world, much of which lies underwater. [SEP] Ben’s Cave, also known as Bats Cave for reasons that will be obvious when you enter, is the most accessible and in fact rather small. [SEP] It links to the larger caves through subterranean tunnels. [SEP] The pool in the bottom has layers of fresh water lying on top of salt water. [SEP] Remains of several Lucayan Indians that were found at the cave entrance are now being studied in Nassau. [SEP] The caves are also home to a rare species of crustacean, spelonectes Lucayensis, which is said t

column1: rricane and today you pass over the still dramatic gap from north to central Eleuthera on the man-made Glass Window Bridge. [SEP] The bridge requires continual maintenance because storms, hurricanes, high winds, and heavy seas take a constant toll; in turbulent weather the Atlantic rises in great waves pushing towards the still, calm Caribbean. [SEP] The first settlement after Glass Window Bridge is Gregory Town, a pretty hillside community of colorful houses overlooking a tiny harbor. [SEP] This is the capital of pineapple production in the Bahamas. [SEP] Try the fresh pies from Thompson’s Bakery on the top of a hill east of the harbor. [SEP] Halfway down the island is Governor’s Harbour, a photogenic town set on the sheltered eastern coastline. [SEP] It is a major center for sailors, who
column3: here to stock up on all the essentials, obtain spare parts, and have repairs done. [SEP] Windermere Island, just off the east coast, was once the place to be in the Bahamas, but its smart resort hotel is now closed. [SEP] Jacques Cousteau had a home here and used it as a base for exploring the seas around the other Bahamian islands.

column1: The family of Neville Chamberlain, the British Prime Minister who attempted to negotiate with Hitler before World War II, created a sisal farm on the island, but the attempt failed miserably. [SEP] Andros is famed for its natural attractions: It has the third longest barrier reef in the world, lying just one mile (11⁄2 km) offshore and stretching 140 miles (225 km) down the east coast. [SEP] This makes it a popular destination with divers who
column3: to explore the tidal shallows, the reef, and the deep reef walls, which plunge 6,000 ft (1,829 m) down into the Tongue of the Ocean, the deep passage between Andros and New Providence. [SEP] Numerous species of sea life flourish at every level and contribute to the abundant variety of diving environments available for all ability levels. [SEP] Experienced divers also

column1: The island itself also has peculiarities that separate it from other Bahamian Islands. [SEP] It is the most undulating of the islands; one could even call it hilly, with the highest point of land in the Commonwealth, Mount Alvernia, rising to the heady heights of 216 ft (66m) above sea level. [SEP] Many visitors
column3: to this island, named after an English sea captain called Catt, for its beautiful quiet beaches. [SEP] Fernandez Bay, with its arc of fine sand on the protected western side of the island, is said to be the finest in the Bahamas, and the nearby beach at Old Bight is not far behind in terms of beauty. [SEP] Though you can’t go wrong anywhere on the western coast. [SEP] Mount Alvernia, in the center of the island, is not far from the airfield at New Bight. column1: The interior of San Salvador is dotted with lakes; there is a great deal of marshy land and only one major road. [SEP] Cockburn Town (pronounced “KOE-burn”) is the capital. [SEP] Pride of place in the town goes to the small jail found by the main coast road. [SEP] It’s now a museum because, as one resident said, “we don’t have no need for no jail.” (The opening hours are irregular.) The main road leads around the circumference of the island. [SEP] Heading south from Cockburn Town you’ll first
column3: to Long Bay, the “official” site of Columbus’s landing. [SEP] It is marked by a plain white cross that sits bright and stark against the azure-blue ocean on the seaward side of the road. [SEP] The area has been designated as Landfall Park. [SEP] Another monument, to the 1968 Olympics in Mexico, sits a little way from the cross. [SEP] This depiction of the Olympic rings on a circular plinth is here because the Olympic flame was brought to San Salvador on its way to Mexico. [SEP] At the northeastern corner of the island is Dixon Hill Lighthouse. [SEP] Built in 1856 but improved in subsequent years, it is called the last hand-operated kerosene-powered lighthouse in the Bahamas. [SEP] Its beam can be seen for some 20 miles (32 km).

column1: Walt Disney World They call it the “happiest place on earth,” which may be why more visitors now
column3: here than to any other single attraction anywhere. [SEP] Surprisingly, four of every five are adults. [SEP] Disney World is styled as the most complete vacation destination in existence, offering sports, nightlife, sightseeing, shopping, camping, hotels, and restaurants all connected by an extensive, easy-to-use transportation network. [SEP] The heart of the complex is the 100-acre (40-hectare) Magic Kingdom, where it’s easy to confuse who’s real and who’s artificial. [SEP] This is where the park began and where you can meet all your favorite Disney characters — you’ll be able to shake hands with Mickey and get a hug from Goofy. [SEP] The park has seven sections, including Main Street, USA, with its re-creation of turn-of-the-century America facing the much photographed Cinderella Castle. [

column1: oup of army conspirators, who claimed they acted to prevent a possible coup against Sukarno, kidnapped and killed six army generals. [SEP] In the following days, General Suharto, one of the most senior surviving commanders, isolated the conspirators and effectively seized power. [SEP] The blame for the killings was pinned on the Communist Party, the PKI, which denied any involvement. [SEP] A pogrom was then unleashed, first in Java and next in Bali, with widespread killings of suspected Communists. [SEP] The Chinese minority, mainly shopkeepers, moneylenders, and other small businesspeople, were also a target. [SEP] In common with the other immigrant groups, they had been compelled by law to display the flag of their country of origin, even if a century had passed since their ancestors had
column3: to Indonesia. [SEP] Throughout Indonesia, every Chinese business, marked by the flag of China, and associated in people’s minds with communism, was attacked. [SEP] The numbers killed will never be known: in Bali alone the total casualties may have exceeded 60,000. [SEP] Sukarno’s association with the PKI led to his being forced to yield most of his powers. [SEP] Only his honored role in the independence struggle saved him from trial. [SEP] In 1968 Suharto took over the presidency.

column1: More arduous and serious mountain treks include climbing the active volcano Gunung Batur — a trek of several hours — and the crater rim and lake of Gunung Rinjani (on Lombok), which demands at least three days to complete. [SEP] Massage, both relaxing and therapeutic, is a Balinese tradition that many visitors have
column3: to enjoy. [SEP] The beaches are filled with men and women offering reasonably good massage at prices that are very low. [SEP] Ubud has many good massage centers that offer very professional massage treatment, including mineral baths, all for approximately US$10; hotels and resorts offer similar treatment in more pampering surroundings for considerably more. [SEP] Spectator Sports

column1: plexity. [SEP] Java is the source of the batik for dresses and sarongs sold in fashion shops; Balinese versions are usually much coarser. [SEP] Hawkers will swear that their dress lengths of cheap printed cotton are batik. [SEP] It’s easy to tell that they are not: Printed patterns don’t penetrate fully to the other side, while the real batik will show thin veins of color where the dye runs along tiny cracks in the wax (printed versions may try to simulate this). [SEP] Real batik is always much more expensive. [SEP] Used batik sarongs are highly prized, as their patterns are often no longer produced. [SEP] Used batik can be bought for very low fixed prices at textile shops like Alec, on Jalan Legian in Kuta-Legian. [SEP] Endek or ikat fabrics, using threads dyed in patterns before weaving,
column3: from Gianyar in Bali as well as other Indonesian islands. [SEP] In Bali, only the weavers of Tenganan make grinsing, or double ikat, using pattern-dyed threads for both warp and weft. [SEP] The genuine fabric is justifiably expensive — beware of fakes! [SEP] You can find bold, primitive examples of ikat cloth, especially from islands such as Sumba, Flores, and Timor, in good textile shops. [SEP] Paintings: If you want a unique work of art, you’ll need to study the field. [SEP] Visit the major collections to judge the standard of the best paintings, especially the Neka Museum and Museum Puri Lukisan in Ubud (see page 41) as well as the Arts Centre in Denpasar (see page 37). [SEP] Don’t just assume that a high price guarantees original work.

column1: and: you can easily get to any place on Bali in several hours. [SEP] But to the Balinese, the island is their universe—a world unto itself. [SEP] You will cut traveling time and get to know different areas of Bali in depth if you make overnight stays or visits of a few days in each of the island’s regions. [SEP] Don’t expect—and don’t even try—to rush around seeing all the temples and other cultural attractions on the island, or all those mentioned in this section. [SEP] The island scenery and fleeting glimpses of everyday life are just as rewarding. [SEP] Best of all is to turn a corner and find a procession, perhaps the whole population of a village, dressed in their best and blocking the road. [SEP] Balinese temples, palaces, and other buildings, however exotic or exquisite, only really
column3: to life when filled with ceremonies and the bustle of festivals. [SEP] We have selected some of the most interesting and important attractions, but to truly appreciate and absorb what you see, we suggest that you take a few at a time. [SEP] Start as soon after dawn as possible, when it’s cool and the light is better for photography. [SEP] A prompt start also gives you extra time to reach the more remote areas.

column1: The Southern Resorts Most of Bali’s tourism is concentrated in a tiny fraction of the island, with the vast majority of visitors heading for the “big three” beaches, namely Sanur, Kuta, and Nusa Dua, all within a short drive of the airport. [SEP] Some stretches of sand are so magnificent and the water so warm, it’s hard to believe that they were ignored for so long by the Balinese people, who have traditionally turned away from the sea. [SEP] Now visitors
column3: in the millions from all over the world with little in mind but sun, sand, warm seas, and watersports. [SEP] Sanur

column1: The beach is the real reason to be here, and even though you won’t escape the hawkers, it’s a rest cure after the bustle of the town. [SEP] Swim only between the flags, where Australian-style lifeguards keep watch: the undertow and currents can be hazardous. [SEP] Surf shops abound. [SEP] Towards sunset, a golden light reflects off the sea and local people
column3: out to stroll or paddle in the shallows. [SEP] Young men play soccer on the sand or join the tourists in a volleyball game, while the eager beach masseuses rustle up a new wave of business. [SEP] At nightfall, new choices beckon. [SEP] You can inspect Bali’s selection of shops, pick a restaurant, go on a pub crawl, or see a movie and wait for midnight when the discos get into gear.

column1: Ubud Once a magnet for foreign artists and still home to some, Ubud and the cluster of villages around it form the cultural and artistic focus of Bali. [SEP] An increasing number of visitors
column3: on day trips from the coastal resorts, but a better plan is to stay overnight or longer. [SEP] There’s a wide choice of accommodations, ranging from cheap homestays and charming middle range hotels to high-priced luxury hideaways in the countryside just outside Ubud. [SEP] Day trippers only get to see the commercialism and chaos in Ubud’s main streets. [SEP] Just a short walk away, however, you’re among the green, peaceful rice terraces and jungle-filled river gorges that have captivated Bali’s visitors for decades and are so much a part of the region’s legendary mystique.

column1: ul alternative — taking in the raja’s second fancy creation, the water playground in the hills at Tirtagangga 5 km (3 miles) northwest of Amlapura. [SEP] This water garden was only established after World War II, and despite being nearer to the eruption, it was spared serious damage. [SEP] You can cool off in the spring-fed pools built for the raja’s family, and there are places to stay if you want to enjoy the refreshing air and magical dawn light. [SEP] One losmen is inside the water garden area. [SEP] On the road north, a right fork at Culik leads eastwards to Amed, a quiet fishing and salt-panning village spread out along several kilometers of beaches. [SEP] Here, many losmen (small, family-run hotels), as well as a few pleasant middle-range hotels have sprung up to serve travelers who
column3: to snorkel and dive in the clear waters. [SEP] The Mountains

column1: Lovina Beach The beaches west of Singaraja began to attract escapist travelers in the early 1970s, and simple and fairly inexpensive accommodations were built to house them. [SEP] Slowly the number of visitors grew and the small homestays turned themselves into larger bungalow-type hotels. [SEP] Today, tour groups
column3: for short stays and, as everywhere in Bali, standards and prices are steadily going up. [SEP] Actually, Lovina is not one village but a string of small ones, starting 6 km (4 miles) west of Singaraja and continuing for 10 km (6 miles) up the coast road. [SEP] Shops, restaurants, and moneychangers are scattered along the busy stretch. [SEP] The beach itself is shallow and gently shelving, making it an ideal place for small children. [SEP] There is calm water on the inside of the reef and good snorkeling over it. [SEP] Lovina’s dark sand is less inviting than the white or golden variety at the southern resorts, and gets too hot to walk on in bare feet in the middle of the day.

column1: At Dencarik, to the west of Lovina, the road inland climbs a steep hill before reaching the orange-roofed building of the Buddhist monastery known as Brahma Vihara Arama. [SEP] Nearby, at Banjar Tega, the warm springs (signposted Air Panas) have been piped into a public swimming pool, attractively shaded. [SEP] There is a smaller and hotter pool, a natural shower, and reasonably clean changing rooms. [SEP] The market town of Seririt is a busy junction with one road leading across the island to Tabenan and eventually to Denpasar and the other following the coastal route westward. [SEP] Celukanbawang Bay, 12 km (7 miles) from Seririt, is likely to be
column3: an important port if development plans are realized. [SEP] So far there’s a wharf, but rarely a ship to be seen. [SEP] After about another 25 km (16 miles) of sparsely settled shoreline, you’ll

column1: From a study of their plants and animals, the 19th-century naturalist Alfred Wallace divided the Indonesian islands into a western group, regarded as part of southeast Asia, and an eastern group, which belonged geographically to Australia/Oceania. [SEP] He then drew the line between the two through the deep Lombok Strait separating Bali and Lombok. [SEP] The division is not quite so clear-cut now, but the basic principle of the “Wallace Line” is still accepted. [SEP] For many years, the island of Lombok was the domain of the Sasaks, a people who had
column3: from the Asian mainland by way of Java and Bali. [SEP] They were animists who revered the spirits they believed to be in the living things and inanimate objects around them. [SEP] As Islam spread through the islands (apart from Bali) some people in Lombok adopted it in a version of their own, Wektu Telu, which retained many influences of animism. [SEP] Today, a majority of people are more or less orthodox Muslims: As you travel about Lombok, you will notice many exotic country mosques with their domes and arabesque arcades, as well as the growing numbers of young women who wear robes and headscarves. [SEP] The first succession of Balinese invasions started in the 16th century. [SEP] For a while, most of Lombok was governed from Karangasem in Bali. [SEP] Later, the Balinese province in Lombo

column1: ere laid out for a 19th-century raja to remind him of Gunung Rinjani and its crater lake when he became too infirm to make the journey to the real mountain. [SEP] The resemblance is harder to see now that an extra pool and a rectangular swimming pool have been added. [SEP] To the north of Narmada at Lingsar, a new spring is said to have burst into life to greet the Balinese when they came to Lombok, and they chose the site for an ecumenical temple intended to bring together people of different religions. [SEP] The upper compound is reserved for the Hindus. [SEP] The pool in the Wektu Telu temple is the home of big plump eels, overfed on offerings of boiled eggs which are conveniently sold by vendors at the gate. [SEP] In another enclosure, the stones wound in white cloth with a yellow sash
column3: from Gunung Rinjani, and Chinese Taoists have put mirrors there to repel the malevolent spirits. [SEP] At Suranadi, in the gardens just east of Lingsar, eggs are on the menu again, for the residents of a pond in the Temple of the Holy Eels. [SEP] You can swim, too, in a separate spring-fed pool or at the old Dutch-built hotel. [SEP] You can also play golf at the nearby country club.

column1: The Gilis are known for their tranquility, surrounded by sparkling waters. [SEP] Snorkeling, diving, and sunning are the islands’ chief activities. [SEP] The boats that ply the route from Bangsal to the islands wait for a full load of 15 to 20 people. [SEP] In July and August that won’t take long, but out of season you can face a delay unless you pay for the empty places or charter a whole boat (fares are low and fixed). [SEP] There’s losmen or bungalow accommodations and a growing number of new, very comfortable small hotels on all three islands, as well as small stores where you can buy basic food, bottled water, and cold drinks. [SEP] Warungs serve simple meals, mostly the standard Indonesian-style dishes and whatever fresh fish has
column3: in. [SEP] Mountain Treks

column1: Catalonia’s legendary founding father also gave the budding nation its flag of four horizontal red stripes on a gold field, the oldest still in use in Europe. [SEP] Legend holds that the stripes were etched in Wilfred’s blood, drawn on his shield as an escutcheon by the fingers of the Frankish king after the count had courageously defended his overlord in a battle. [SEP] When King Louis V refused to
column3: to their aid against Moorish raiders, the counts of Barcelona declared their independence in 988, a date celebrated as Catalonia’s birth as a nation-state. [SEP] The Catalan nation was soon enlarged through marriage and military adventure. [SEP] Ramón Berenguer III (1096–1131) captured Mallorca, Ibiza, and Tarragona from the Moors and acquired the French county of Provence through his heiress wife. [SEP] His successor, Ramón Berenguer IV, united Catalonia with neighboring Aragón by marriage, and his son Alfonso II became the first joint-king of Aragón and Catalonia and was known as “the Emperor of the Pyrenees.” [SEP] His kingdom extended all the way to Nice. [SEP] But much of this territory was lost by the next king, Alfonso’s son Peter the Catholic, who picked the losing side in the Frenc

column1: Tibidabo The first bright, clear morning or late afternoon of your visit, head for Tibidabo, the 542-meter (1,778-foot) peak that overlooks Barcelona. [SEP] The views of the city are breathtaking. [SEP] You can clearly make out the Sagrada Familia and the grid plan of the Eixample. [SEP] Families
column3: here on summer evenings to enjoy the 1950s-style amusement park, and weekends are crowded with joggers and cyclists. [SEP] You can also climb Torre de Collserola, by the English architect Sir Norman Foster, or visit the church of the Sagrat Corazón. [SEP] A neo-Gothic work by Enric Sagnier, the church is surmounted by a monumental figure of Christ, one of the city’s landmarks. [SEP] To reach the summit take the FCG train (not the metro) to “Avda. Tibidabo” from the Plaça de Catalunya. [SEP] From here a Tramvia Blau (blue tram) runs daily in the summer, Saturdays and Sundays the rest of the year, taking you up to the funicular station, past stately mansions. [SEP] In five minutes the funicular (closed mid-October through February) lifts you through pine woods to the top, where you have a spe

column1: Recreation and Sports Although most visitors to the capital do not
column3: for outdoor pursuits or sports, Beijing does have a variety of recreational activities. [SEP] Most international hotels maintain full-service fitness centers with exercise machines, saunas, indoor swimming pools, and other facilities such as tennis courts, with day rates for non-guests. [SEP] The city parks are fine places for jogging, exercises, tai chi, walking, and other early morning workouts. [SEP] Golf, bowling, and billiards are the three most popular recreational sports. [SEP] Beijing also offers bungee jumping (at the Shidu Bungee Jumping Facility in the Fangshan District), paintball (at Color Me Purple in Wanfangting Park), rock climbing (at the Qidagudu Climbing Club in the Xuanwu District), horseback riding (check with the Movenpick Hotel), and shooting (at the China North Shoot

column1: Western Hills When China’s rulers really wanted to escape the heat of the city, they went farther west than the Summer Palace to the Western Hills (Xi Shan), romantically known today as Fragrant Hills Park (Xiangshan Gong yuan). [SEP] Imperial villas first dotted these hillsides — 27 km (17 miles) from Beijing — more than 800 years ago. [SEP] But it was the Qing Emperor Qianlong who converted the Western Hills into a formal mountain retreat for the enjoyment of the court, complete with its own temples, lakes, gardens, and even a zoo. [SEP] Late autumn is the favorite season for park visitors these days, when leaves turn a fiery red. [SEP] However, locals as well as tourists
column3: to the Western Hills year round for the natural beauty and historic sites. [SEP] Two renowned temples still survive in the Western Hills. [SEP] Near the park’s north gate are the four great halls of the Temple of the Sleeping Buddha (Wo Fo Si). [SEP] In the final hall (Wo Fo Dian) there is a 5-m (16-ft) lacquered statue of the reclining Buddha (dated 1321) about to attain nirvana.

column1: Reduced by war and the Wall to a bleak no-man’s-land, the square that was at one time the busiest in Europe has burst back into life in the most invigorating fashion. [SEP] What was once a scar on the landscape, epitomizing the division of the city and country, is now a thriving arts, entertainment, shopping and business center. [SEP] The impact of the towering, modern buildings, made almost predominantly from glass, is breathtaking. [SEP] Investment from corporations such as Daimler-Chrysler and Sony has resulted in the construction of shopping malls, a theater, casino, a splendid hotel, cinemas, and a film museum. [SEP] Almost 100,000 people a day
column3: here to marvel at the striking architecture and explore the latest attractions in this ever-changing city. [SEP] The Sony Center is a vibrant entertainment complex, contained with a central courtyard under a glass ceiling. [SEP] Technophiles can check out the latest gadgets at Sony’s first European department store, while film buffs will be intrigued by the exhibits at the excellent new Film Museum Berlin. [SEP] A fascinating contrast to the futuristic architecture and technological content can be found in the elegant remains of the old Grandhotel Esplanade, now preserved behind glass walls. [SEP] The nearby Arkaden shopping center became a firm favorite with city shoppers as soon as it opened in 1998, and the cafés, casino, and theater in Marlene-Dietrich-Platz pay tribute to the city’s mo
