column1: Sweeping eastwards from the gate, this grand 61-m (200-ft) -wide avenue, literally named “Beneath the Linden Trees,” was Berlin’s showcase boulevard. [SEP] Frederick the Great saw it as the center of his royal capital, and it became the most prestigious address in town. [SEP] Some of its splendor fell victim to 19th-century building speculation, but the avenue remained fashionable until the bombs of World War II reduced it to rubble. [SEP] Now the trees have been replanted and the most important buildings restored. [SEP] Its western end is dominated by the Russian Federation Embassy on the right as you
column3: from Brandenburg Gate. [SEP] Close by is the smartest hotel in town; the supremely elegant Hotel Adlon was recently built on the site of the original hotel of the same name, which was a 1930s Berlin legend. [SEP] Continuing east, you pass the unprepossessing modern façade of the Komische Oper, one of Berlin’s most important opera companies. [SEP] The ugly exterior is the result of post-war reconstruction; happily, the magnificently over-the-top original gilded interior has been retained.

column1: restaurant on the fourth floor is the place to calm your shattered nerves. [SEP] The Deutscher Dom now houses a fascinating exhibition, Fragen an die deutsche Geschichte (German History Under Question), which was previously in the Reichstag. [SEP] This frank examination of Germany’s social and political history cleverly combines documents, photographs, and radio broadcasts to chronicle the rise of Fascism and the development of democracy. [SEP] The descriptive panels are all in German, but audio guides and information booklets are available in English and French. [SEP] A short stroll leads to Friedrichstraße, where over 100,000 m of GDR architectural monstrosity have been demolished and replaced by a very elegant development of designer shops, offices, and apartments. [SEP] French élan has
column3: to Berlin in the form of a branch of the famous department store, Galeries Lafayette, at Quartier 207. [SEP] The sophisticated Art Deco styling of Quartier 206, home to some very exclusive designer boutiques, is the work of Americans Pen, Cobb, Freed, and Partners. [SEP] Walking along Friedrichstraße, you can only marvel at the changes that have been made here since reunification. [SEP] Nowhere is this brought home more strongly than at Checkpoint Charlie, that infamous border crossing between East and West. [SEP] Today, the barbed wire and barriers are gone, but the memories remain, housed in the fascinat-ing Haus am Checkpoint Charlie Museum.

column1: On the Grunewald’s west side, along Havelchaussee, the Grunewaldturm (Grunewald Tower) is a Neo-Gothic tower built in 1897 to commemorate the 100th birthday of King Wilhelm I. You can climb the 205 steps to reach the 55-m- (180-ft- ) high observation platform for views as far as Potsdam. [SEP] Ferry stations in the area offer boat rides on the River Havel and forest lakes, and the east bank of the Havel is lined with sandy beaches as far as the Wannsee lakes. [SEP] The waterfront near Wannsee S-Bahn station is a crowded spot where city-dwellers
column3: and let their hair down on warm spring and summer days. [SEP] The water bustles with pleasure boats and ferries, and you can cruise all the way to Spandau and Potsdam from here. [SEP] Strandbad Wannsee is Berlin’s biggest beach, and the longest inland one in Europe. [SEP] West of the Großer Wannsee, Königstraße crosses Berliner Forst, an extension of the Grunewald to Glienicke Park. [SEP] Its whimsical landscaping of little hills, bridges, and ponds was the work of Peter Josef Lenné in the early 19th century. [SEP] Schloß Glienicke (1828) is a rather austere Neo-Classical edifice, but the nearby cloister, villa, and garden houses add a romantic touch.

column1: The capital of Bermuda since 1815, Hamilton is a very small and friendly city, despite its importance in the world of finance, banking, and insurance. [SEP] It is the heart of government and decision making, and because it is the only container port on the island, it is also the center of shipping and trade. [SEP] Local people gravitate here for shopping and entertainment, and visitors crowd the streets in summer when the cruise ships are in town. [SEP] Front Street runs along the water and is the first part of town seen by cruise passengers as ships
column3: to shore. [SEP] It is the life and soul of Hamilton and a focus for many activities, especially during the summer months. [SEP] A long row of pastel-painted buildings offer the best in tax-free shopping: jewelry, liquor, clothing, and crystal. [SEP] Explore the narrow alleyways that lead off Front Street to discover small shops selling collectibles or locally designed arts and crafts, or small restaurants offering local seafood. [SEP] On Front Street itself there are a number of restaurants with verandas on the first floor, where you can have a drink or meal and watch the world go by. [SEP] At the west end of Front Street, on the waterfront, you will find the Visitor Service Bureau and the terminal for the local ferries that ply across Great and Little Sound from Hamilton to the southern an

column1: was built around 1725 on land bought by John Trimingham II. [SEP] Originally, the family built ships and operated a wharf in front of the house, “at the foot of the Lane,” as the end of Hamilton Harbour was then known. [SEP] The bottom floor of the house was used to store goods and equipment, while the upper floor provided living quarters. [SEP] In 1961 the house was acquired by the Historic Monuments Trust, precursor to the Bermuda National Trust, but it was still occupied by elderly Trimingham family members until 1990. [SEP] Two rooms on the upper level are open to the public, where Trimingham furniture and family portraits can be seen. [SEP] Just as popular are the gardens, set against the water’s edge. [SEP] A 300-year-old tamarind tree sheds comforting shade over the house, and ducks
column3: from the water to share your sandwiches. [SEP] If you turn up Berry Hill Road at the same roundabout, you will find the entrance to the Botanical Gardens and Camden (bus route [SEP]1). [SEP] Camden was designated as the official residence of Bermuda’s premier after self-government began in 1970. [SEP] It is an impressive colonial building with painted shutters and fretwork. [SEP] The Botanical Gardens that surround the house were inaugurated in 1898 and doubled in size to 15 hectares (36 acres) in 1921. [SEP] There are large glass houses with cacti and orchids along with formal gardens, lawns, and an aromatic garden designed for the enjoyment of blind visitors. [SEP] There are also tables under the trees in the rolling landscape in front of Camden for picnics. [SEP] The whole area is a deli

column1: The South Road You will
column3: first to the Elbow Beach Resort and the nearby public Bermuda Beach. [SEP] The resort is one of the premier hotels on the island and sits on a long stretch of sand that is for hotel guests exclusively. [SEP] South Road travels on top of the cliffs and offers beautiful views of the sand dunes and beaches below. [SEP] Don’t worry about trying to take in these views while driving, for there are many stopping places along the way where you can take photographs or simply enjoy the panorama. [SEP] The way to each beach is marked with a wooden sign, which leads to parking areas for bicycles and cars off the main road. [SEP] Once you reach Warwick Long Bay there are a series of public beaches that allow you to walk along the sand or find a patch to call your own for the day. [SEP] Miles of footpath

column1: erman engineers at the time. [SEP] The gunning placements held “disappearing” guns, which could not be seen from land or sea. [SEP] Other gunning placements were also added by US engineers during World War II. [SEP] A sturdy caponier (a small fortified room with openings for rifles) was to act as a last defense if the battlements were overrun. [SEP] It was never needed, as the fort never saw any action, and today the ramparts offer panoramic views of Great Sound. [SEP] There are 9 hectares (22 acres) of grassland all around the fort where you can enjoy a picnic. [SEP] Just beyond the fort, watch out for a narrow lane to the right with a sign for the Heydon Trust Chapel. [SEP] This simple place of worship, on land set aside for personal reflection, is open at all hours for those who want to
column3: and pray. [SEP] (The building is listed on maps of 1616 as a personal residence.) [SEP] Visitors can admire the architecture and see the old water storage tank that collects water for use inside. [SEP] The village of Somerset lies only half a mile beyond the fort. [SEP] It is a small settlement but has many shops that are branches of larger Hamilton stores and also a couple of well-regarded restaurants for a leisurely lunch.

column1: Taking Cavendish Road out of Hamilton leads to Middle Road, which runs through the widest section of land in Bermuda. [SEP] Although they are never more than a mile from the sea, the people who live here are considered country dwellers by those who live on the coast. [SEP] You will
column3: first to the Arboretum (bus route [SEP]3), 9 hectares (22 acres) of lawns and woods filled with native trees. [SEP] Separate swathes of land concentrate on collections of ficus and palms, with an area of general woodland beyond. [SEP] It’s a great place for children to run wild or explore in the undergrowth. [SEP] Less than a mile past the Arboretum, you will find two churches on the right side of the road, backed by hundreds of white painted family tombs on the hillside. [SEP] The larger building first catches the eye, but it is the smaller whitewashed Old Devonshire Church that holds the interest. [SEP] The church originally erected here in 1716 was totally destroyed by a mysterious explosion on Easter Sunday, 31 March 1970. [SEP] The building on the site today is an exact replica of the

column1: South Road
column3: s to an abrupt end at Tucker’s Town Bay, a small jetty and inlet with yachts bobbing gently in the water. [SEP] To get across Castle Harbour to St. George’s, you must go north here, taking Paynter’s Road to Harrington Sound. [SEP] Then drive up along Harrington Sound Road to reach the Causeway to St. George’s. [SEP] On your way up Harrington Sound Road, you will

column1: Around the corner in Featherbed Alley, you will find Featherbed Alley Printery, a small museum with a working model of the Gutenberg printing press first brought from England by Joseph Stockdale in 1783 and used to produce the Bermuda Gazette — first issued on 17 January 1784. [SEP] The building where the paper was originally printed is the Stockdale House, on the corner of Printer’s Alley and Needle and Thread Alley. [SEP] Stockdale was an extremely industrious man and also a man of foresight, as he also organized and ran the first postal service on the island. [SEP] Continue along Duke of Kent Street and you will
column3: to the Unfinished Church, an elegant edifice originally begun in the 1870s when St. Peter’s Church was badly damaged by a storm and thought to be beyond repair. [SEP] As construction proceeded, however, the local population decided that they would rather invest their money in repairing the old church and work on the unfinished church was immediately stopped. [SEP] Had the church been completed, it would have been a fitting place of worship. [SEP] Continue to the right of the Unfinished Church, up Government Hill Road and through the rolling fairways of St. George’s Golf Course, one of the most challenging on the island, until you reach the coast. [SEP] Here you will find Tobacco Bay, a small stretch of sheltered beach popular with the cruise passengers who disembark at St. George’s and want

column1: The Esplanade Explore westwards from Charles Street, and you’ll
column3: to the Esplanade, a long narrow park along the Charles River. [SEP] Here Bostonians enjoy jogging, walking, cycling, in-line skating, or just watching the river life. [SEP] The much-loved Boston Pops Orchestra performs in the Art Deco Hatch Memorial Shell during July; the 4th of July performance is a knockout (see page 84). [SEP] Along the Downtown Freedom trail to Downtown Crossing

column1: Faneuil Hall Marketplace Annually 14 million visitors
column3: to Faneuil Hall, the great “Cradle of Liberty” and marketplace. [SEP] It’s very commercial, but very alluring and one of the most successful restorations anywhere. [SEP] Huguenot merchant Peter Faneuil (pronounced fannel, fan’l or funnel), gave it to the city in 1742. [SEP] The original, consisting of a town hall above and a market below was burned down in 1762, but was swiftly rebuilt. [SEP] Here on the second floor Boston’s great orators raised their voices against British tyranny, against slavery, and female oppression. [SEP] It’s still used for meetings and assemblies. [SEP] The vast painting behind the stage shows Daniel Webster and John Calhoun arguing over the Union. [SEP] On the third floor the Museum of the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Massachusetts, the oldest militi

column1: slavery, and female oppression. [SEP] It’s still used for meetings and assemblies. [SEP] The vast painting behind the stage shows Daniel Webster and John Calhoun arguing over the Union. [SEP] On the third floor the Museum of the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Massachusetts, the oldest militia in the nation founded in 1637, displays historic flags, paintings, and military memorabilia (open Monday–Friday, 9am–5pm). [SEP] The building’s most legendary feature is the grasshopper weathervane. [SEP] No one knows really why tinsmith Shem Drowne chose the grasshopper motif, although some say it symbolizes good fortune. [SEP] In 1805 Charles Bulfinch enlarged the hall. [SEP] Across the plaza from Fanueil Hall the three Quincy market buildings fill with crowds of locals and visitors, who
column3: to feast on chowder, seafood, deli sandwiches, pizza, and an array of ethnic cuisines. [SEP] They also

column1: The Chic and the Victorian A stroll along Newbury Street — the city’s most expensive real estate — is the most civilized and congenial of Boston experiences. [SEP] This is where the chic and the conservative
column3: to furnish their homes with art and antiques, wrap their bodies in designer fashion, have their hair styled in upmarket salons, and wine, dine, and drink iced coffee al fresco in summer. [SEP] Image and appearance take center stage here, both in the showcase windows and the personas of the people looking at them. [SEP] Every display — whether of fine art, ice cream, or fashion — is worth a picture. [SEP] Some of the galleries exhibit works by major artists. [SEP] Notice the architecture as well: At the end of the converted carriage houses, the less genteel eastern end gives way to series of alternate classic bow- and flat-fronted townhouses. [SEP] Take a detour along the way down one of the side streets, alphabetically arranged from A to H, starting at the Public Garden (they’re named after

column1: recious, devoid of cornices and fancy wrought iron. [SEP] When the marsh of Back Bay was filled in during the 1860s, water flooded into this area, forcing the streets and houses to be raised on pilings. [SEP] Take Tremont Street south and cross over the Massachusetts Turnpike into the South End. [SEP] Come if only to savor one (or more) of its great restaurants, a clutch of chic bistros on Tremont Street around Clarendon. [SEP] Like so much of Boston, the South End began as a landfill project, but it soon lost out in desirability to Back Bay. [SEP] A multi-ethnic mix of Hispanic, Irish, West Indian, and Greek, the community is also home to Boston’s largest gay community. [SEP] Some districts — to the south of Shawmut Avenue, for example — are best avoided. [SEP] In others, though, you will
column3: across bright community murals and perhaps a reggae band playing in a local park. [SEP] The neighborhood boasts (justifiably) a fine concentration of Victorian terraced residences. [SEP] Bow brick houses, their steep stoops (or steps) framed with scrolled black railings, are set off by parks, the finest examples being Union Park Square, situated just off Tremont Street, and Rutland and Concord squares both farther to the south.

column1: There’s an even better view from the top of the 253-ft (77-m) Pilgrim Monument in Provincetown. [SEP] It’s called the Pilgrim monument because this is where the Pilgrims actually landed first before moving on to Plymouth. [SEP] The museum at the base of the tower tells the story. [SEP] P-Town, is a fabled place. [SEP] Although the main street is crowded and lined with commercial tourist trinket stores, it still has a magical atmosphere, because it has an “anything goes” attitude. [SEP] It is the East Coast’s gay mecca (along with the Hamptons, and Cherry Grove and the Pines on Fire Island). [SEP] Same-sex couples walk the streets hand in hand, and outrageous transvestites entertain in the cabarets. [SEP] Families
column3: to browse the stores selling T-shirts, and scrimshaw and driftwood curios, and to enjoy the beaches and the fishing and whale-watch trips. [SEP] In the early 20th century Provincetown was a major art colony and there are still numerous art galleries, particularly at the east end of town. [SEP] In summer, the town is swamped and every guesthouse filled. [SEP] In winter, it’s quiet. [SEP] Many of the commercial stores close and only the residents remain — a community of artists, Portuguese fishermen, and a handful of restaurateurs. [SEP] You can visit Provincetown for a day (see page 110), but if you don’t stay longer, you’ll miss half the fun.

column1: Films Hungarians take their movies seriously, and Hungarian directors have
column3: up with lastingly interesting works. [SEP] But the tourist is out of luck, because the domestic product is incomprehensible even locally and most of the foreign films are dubbed into Hungarian. [SEP] Folklore

column1: [SEP] Next door, number 18 was built as a merchant’s house in the ﬁrst half of the 15th century. [SEP] Used as the Arany Sas (Golden Eagle) pharmacy from 1750 until 1913, it is now the most attractive of this area’s small museums. [SEP] Beautiful old majolica vessels are the stars of an atmospheric re-creation of the pharmacy, and there are also informative displays on potions, practices, and alchemy in the Budapest of this era. [SEP] The ﬁnal street of this district to be explored is the leafy Tóth Arpád sétány. [SEP] This promenade, situated along the western ramparts, offers views of the Buda Hills and the huge Southern Railway Station (Déli pályaudavar) rather than a glorious Danube panorama. [SEP] Nonetheless, this is a delightful stroll, particularly in early evening, when the locals
column3: out to enjoy the fresh air. [SEP] At the northern end, various cannon signal the entrance to the Museum of Military History (Hadtörténeti Múzeum). [SEP] It’s an extensive exhibition and popular with school-children, but the section dedicated to the 1956 uprising is the most memorable for older visitors. [SEP] The Royal Palace

column1: Margaret Island (Margit-sziget) The elite of the Roman empire escaped everyday cares on this leafy oasis between the two banks, and in later eras princes and plutocrats did likewise. [SEP] Today wealthy tourists enjoy the thermal facilities and treatments offered at the two international-class hotels on the island. [SEP] The leisure establishment of most interest to visitors is the huge outdoor Palatinus Baths (Palatinus strand) which includes thermal pools and boasts a capacity of 20,000 swimmers and sunbathers. [SEP] The island is not just for tourists, however: Budapestis of all ages
column3: here to walk, run, swim, play tennis or team games, or simply sunbathe. [SEP] It’s also a famous spot for courting couples. [SEP] The island is 2 km (11⁄2 miles) long and only a few hundred yards at the widest part. [SEP] Many of its estimated population of 10,000 trees are now more than a century old, and large areas of the island are lawned and landscaped. [SEP] Best of all, cars (with a few exceptions) are prohibited, thus preserving the island’s peace and quiet.

column1: Váci utca runs into the ever-busy, yet somehow relaxed, Vörösmarty tér. [SEP] This is one of Pest’s favourite gathering places, often lined with craft stalls and resounding to a brass band. [SEP] After a browse through Luxus department store, it’s probably time for coffee and cakes at Gerbeaud, doyen of Budapest’s coffee-house scene since 1884. [SEP] If the sumptuous high-ceilinged interior is a little too formal for your liking, then take a terrace seat and watch the world go by. [SEP] Stroll a few yards towards the river and you will
column3: to yet another pleasant and lively square, Vigadó tér, which has the advantage of a riverside location with Castle Hill views. [SEP] Here, too, you will find craft stalls and any number of buskers. [SEP] A vibrant café-restaurant comprises one side of the square, but the dominant building is the splendid Vigadó theatre. [SEP] The interior hall is an acoustically perfect auditorium renovated in 1980 (its predecessors having twice perished in war and revolution), but the façade has been gloriously restored in mid-19th-century Hungarian-Eastern style. [SEP] The list of performers and conductors who have graced the Vigadó theatre is an impressive Who’s Who of the past 150 years of European classical music: Liszt, Brahms, Wagner, Mahler, Bartók, Prokoﬁev, Casals, Björling, and von Karajan. [SEP]

column1: of the Ethnographical Museum. [SEP] Catch the number 8 bus departing from the terminal next to the HEV station, and ask for the “Skanzen.” [SEP] There are also regular buses from the Tourinform ofﬁce, on the road from the bus station to the centre. [SEP] The 46-hectare (115-acre) museum site will eventually contain ten “villages” of real houses, churches, mills, farm buildings, workshops, and smithys, dating mostly from the late 18th to the early 20th century, and culled from all over Hungary. [SEP] At present there are only three settlements to view, but even these will occupy you for at least half a day and possibly longer. [SEP] It is a fascinating and picturesque simulation of old rural Hungary, brought to life by active craftspeople, gingerbread makers, and other “rural folk.” (Try to
column3: on the ﬁrst or third Sunday of the month, when there are several different craft demonstrations.) An excellent guide book giving the general history of the villages and buildings, and details about individual interiors, is available for purchase. [SEP] Don’t miss climbing up the hill to visit the Greek Catholic Church from Mándok (in northeast Hungary), originally built in 1670, and boasting a painted iconostasis. [SEP] The village is closed from November to April.

column1: The North Shore Driving from Budapest and navigating the lake in an counter-clockwise direction (along the perimeter Highway 71), the ﬁrst settlement of any size is at Balatonalmádi. [SEP] There is a medieval chapel in the parish church, but most people
column3: here to enjoy the beach — the biggest and one of the best-equipped along the northern shore, with space for 12,000 sunbathing bodies. [SEP] Signs for the beach read strand, but that won’t guarantee you a sandy or even pebbly foreshore — it simply means the lake edge, which may be sand, lawn, or even concrete. [SEP] Balatonfüred, some 13 km (8 miles) farther west, has a history as a spa stretching back to Roman times. [SEP] The main square, called Gyógy tér (meaning Health/Therapeutic Square), is a handsome place where the local mineral water bubbles up from the ground beneath a pagoda-like well-head. [SEP] On three sides of the square stand grand old buildings: the 18th-century Horváth House, once an inn, now a miner’s sanatorium; the Trade Union Sanatorium of 1802, and the Cardiac Hospital

column1: The American Pioneers The first Americans to
column3: to California from the eastern states were Boston fur traders taking the Cape Horn route at the end of the 18th century. [SEP] They didn’t stay for long, but gradually other traders and fur trappers began to arrive overland through Utah, Nevada, Arizona, and New Mexico, settling only in small numbers until the famous covered wagons began their heroic treks of the 1840s. [SEP] The hardships the pioneers suffered in the Sierra Nevada mountains, Death Valley, and the Mojave Desert became the stuff of California legend, the most tragic being the fate of 87 pioneers who set out from Illinois in 1846. [SEP] While attempting to cross the Sierra Nevada, George Donner’s wagon train became snowed in, and from November until February was stuck high in the mountains north of Lake Tahoe, at a point now

column1: The reform movement, intent on breaking the political power of the big corporations, attacked corrupt practices in administration, public finances, and banking, but did nothing to oppose the businessmen’s traditional resistance to unions and more liberal labor laws. [SEP] There was also a campaign of official discrimination against Chinese and Japanese immigrants, excluding them from owning land and preventing further immigration. [SEP] All kinds of produce grew large and lush in California’s fertile, irrigated soil, but the most financially profitable thing to
column3: out of the Californian earth was oil. [SEP] Drilling had begun in the 1860s but didn’t take off until 1892. [SEP] By the 1920s, the derricks of the Standard, Union, and Shell oil companies had sprouted all over the Los Angeles basin. [SEP] In that one decade, the state’s oil revenues were $2.5 billion, $500 million more than all the gold the Sierras yielded in a century. [SEP] Sunny, oil-rich Los Angeles was therefore the perfect place for the car to emerge as an everyday household accessory. [SEP] From 1920 to 1930 L.A.’s population more than doubled, and the number of private cars increased fivefold. [SEP] Noting the central position of the “pursuit of happiness” in America’s Declaration of Independence, the Los Angeles Times asked in 1926: “How can one pursue happiness by any swifter and

column1: Watersports If you get no other exercise while you’re in California, it would be difficult to go without at least one day of swimming at the beach. [SEP] It’s no coincidence that most of the United States’ champion swimmers
column3: from Southern California. [SEP] In the middle-class neighborhoods of Los Angeles county it seems that every other house has its own swimming pool — from the air you see the mass of turquoise blobs as you fly into the airport. [SEP] Surfing, snorkeling, scuba diving, sailing, fishing, waterskiing, and windsurfing can all be enjoyed at various points on the coast. [SEP] Everyone has their favorite beach or bay, and some are better for one sport than another.

column1: Thunder Bay For vacationers, this town strategically located on Lake Superior’s northwest shore is a springboard to the national parks of Ontario’s interior. [SEP] But it’s also worth taking a look first at the impressive port facilities of this western terminus of the St. Lawrence–Great Lakes Seaway, which has given Thunder Bay its second name: the Lakehead. [SEP] Freighters
column3: 3,200 km (1,920 miles) inland from the Atlantic to take on grain shipments from the Prairie Provinces or bring other heavy cargo to all points west in both Canada and the United States. [SEP] Starting out from the centrally located North Marina, a harbor cruise takes you around the gigantic fortress-like grain silos for a close-up view of the ships in dock. [SEP] A longer cruise from the same marina follows the Kaministikwia River to Old Fort William (20 minutes by car), the handsomely reconstructed trading post of the Nor’Westers, intrepid rivals of the Hudson’s Bay Company (see page 16). [SEP] Sheep graze the courtyard lawns, bread is still made in the bakery, and the cookhouse provides lusty country fare. [SEP] In the company store you’ll see the kind of simple copper and pewter utensils

column1: The 19th-century exhibits include works by Turner, Constable, Pissarro, Monet, Dégas, and Cézanne. [SEP] Klimt and James Ensor provide the transition to the 20th century, well represented by Matisse, Picasso, Braque, and Francis Bacon. [SEP] Contemporary Art. [SEP] The collections in which American artists
column3: to the fore present works by Jackson Pollock, Barnett Newman, Kenneth Noland, the Pop Art of James Rosenquist, Andy Warhol, and Claes Oldenburg, the Minimalist sculpture of Donald Judd and Dan Flavin, and Conceptualists such as Solo Lewitt and Joseph Kosuth. [SEP] The most important of contemporary Canadians here include Guido Molinari, Yves Gaucher, and Michael Snow. [SEP] Canadian Collections. [SEP] Besides some classics of the 19th century evoking the life and landscapes of the early settlement, the best works are from Tom Thomson and the Group of Seven (see page 63). [SEP] Look for Thomson’s Jack Pine, A. Y. Jackson’s Red Maple, Lawren Harris’s North Shore, Lake Superior, murals by Thomson, Arthur Lismer, and J. E. H. MacDonald, and Emily Carr’s Indian Hut, Queen Charlotte Islands. [SEP

column1: Upper Canada Village Here, 86 km (53 miles) southeast of Ottawa, the two strands of the region’s history
column3: together in the meticulous recreation of a 19th-century pioneering village, perhaps the best of the country’s many historical showpieces. [SEP] The homes of the region’s first settlers had to be moved here, east of Morrisburg, when their original location was flooded in the digging of the St. Lawrence Seaway. [SEP] Start your visit by climbing the small fort tower, from which you get an overall view. [SEP] In a peaceful, green canalside setting disturbed only by perky Canada geese, notoriously loud honkers, you’ll find authentic pre-1867 buildings, from the simple timbered sawmill or old schoolhouse to the sophisticated brick-built Crysler Hall in the Palladian style favored by colonial land owners from Ontario to Alabama. [SEP] Crysler was a farmer on whose land an important battle was fou

column1: gs, a grand colonial kitchen in the basement, and the nice added touch of magnificent carved mahogany paneling imported from the old trading company’s French offices. [SEP] Iroquois clothes and artifacts give a hint of life outside the stockade. [SEP] The rue Bonsecours is one of the principal historic residential streets leading from rue Notre-Dame towards the Vieux Port (Old Port). [SEP] The Maison Papineau (Number 440), distinguished by its double row of gabled garrets in the roof, dates back to 1785. [SEP] It is the family home of the controversial 19th-century politician Louis-Joseph Papineau, leader of the militant patriotes but also cautious protector of his seigneurial property (see page 19). [SEP] In 1837, the house nearly burned down in a violent riot, and British soldiers had to
column3: to Papineau’s rescue. [SEP] He fled to the countryside and did not take part in the subsequent insurrection. [SEP] On the corner of rue St-Paul, the older Maison du Calvet was built in 1725 by a prominent Huguenot merchant. [SEP] As a Protestant, Pierre du Calvet was appointed by the British justice of the peace but then ended up in jail himself for selling supplies and information to the American invaders. [SEP] With its broad chimney, fine-grained limestone frames around the doors, and gracefully tapered casement windows, the house is one of the more handsome architectural specimens of the French colonial era. [SEP] The sturdy interior of wide, rough-hewn floorboards and massive pinewood roofbeams is fitted out from the Montréal Museum of Fine Arts with antique Québec furniture, rugs, lan

column1: Founded in the early 19th century by a Scottish fur trader, James McGill, and especially respected for its engineering and medicine faculties, it has a student enrollment of 15,000. [SEP] In 1969, Québécois separatists staged violent but unsuccessful demonstrations to have it transformed into a French-speaking institution. [SEP] (The city’s other English-speaking college is Concordia while the Université de Montréal and the Université du Québec à Montréal are both French-speaking). [SEP] Between Maisonneuve and R. Lévesque boulevards, art and commerce
column3: together at the Place des Arts and Complexe Desjardins. [SEP] The modern cultural center is comprised of a concert hall, two theaters, and a recital room for chamber music. [SEP] At the Salle Wilfrid-Pelletier, 175 rue Ste-Catherine Ouest, home of the Montréal Symphony Orchestra, the elegant tone of the whole complex is set in the foyer decorated with Aubusson tapestries and sculptures in bronze, mahogany, aluminum, and ceramics. [SEP] Notice above the concert hall doors the soapstone carvings of the Inuit sculptor Yununkpuk. [SEP] Across rue Ste-Catherine, you pass through the imposing glass portals of the attractive multilevel shopping center of Complexe Desjardins, opened in 1976 during the grand building spree of the Montréal Olympic Games.

column1: raphy. [SEP] Look out for the whales and grey seals in the gulf. [SEP] Wildlife inside the park includes fat little porcupine, hare, red squirrel, deer, moose and an occasional bear, lynx, and fox. [SEP] Birdwatchers have 200 species to feast their eyes on, with guillemots and cormorants among the easier to spot. [SEP] The town of Gaspé makes its livelihood from fishing — cod and herring. [SEP] It offers good opportunities for sailing and windsurfing (again, wetsuits obligatory). [SEP] On the rue du Monument is a granite cross commemorating the wooden cross that Jacques Cartier planted on behalf of his French sovereign in front of a bemused audience of Iroquois. [SEP] The best hotels are in the resort town of Percé, so this is naturally the most crowded place on the peninsula. [SEP] People
column3: for watersports and to marvel at the cliffs pierced (percé) by the sea. [SEP] Erosion originally created two arches in the 94-m- (82-ft-) high rocks, but one has since crumbled. [SEP] See them at sunrise when they’re pink. [SEP] Take a cruise around Bonaventure Island to view the penguins and puffins. [SEP] THE ATLANTIC

column1: The drive over Lions Gate Bridge to Vancouver’s North Shore suburbs along Marine Drive and the Upper Levels Highway (Route 99) makes a gentle introduction to your exploration of the Pacific coast and interior. [SEP] With a view of the ocean from a setting of tall Douglas firs and red cedars among boulders, and the occasional swift mountain stream, the elegant or rustic houses enjoy a civilized microcosm of the classical B.C. landscape. [SEP] Route 99 turns north at Horseshoe Bay (landing area for the Vancouver Island ferry) to be
column3: the Squamish Highway for a spectacular 100-km (60-mile) drive up to Whistler Mountain. [SEP] The Coastal Mountains

column1: Turn north at Hope to Yale, an old fort of the Hudson’s Bay Company, terminus of its stern-wheelers unable to negotiate the rapids upriver — at low water you can still see their ring tie-ups on the river bank. [SEP] A little museum documents how this sleepy village of a few hundred inhabitants was once a gold rush boomtown and the major construction depot for the C.P.R. The strands of B.C.’s destiny
column3: together where the Fraser Canyon narrows at the torrential rapids of Hell’s Gate. [SEP] For thousands of years, this point in the river’s descent to the ocean was the local native peoples’ favored fishing spot for the salmon swimming to their spawning grounds. [SEP] It was here in 1808 that they helped Nor’Wester fur trader Simon Fraser with his canoe past the rapids, over a swaying ropeway of vines strung along the canyon wall, enabling him to follow to the ocean the river that bears his name. [SEP] In 1914, the C.N.R. blocked the salmon’s passage with rock-blasts through the canyon for the railway. [SEP] The consequent 90 percent reduction of the annual sockeye salmon catch was remedied only 30 years later when multimillion-dollar steel-and-concrete channels were built for the fish. [SEP]

column1: In this region, the great Canadian outdoors really
column3: s into its own. [SEP] The national parks of the Rocky Mountains provide unrivaled opportunities for exhilarating contacts with a wilderness where you can really escape from your fellow man: camping and hiking through the forests; fishing in the myriad lakes and rivers; canoeing and whitewater rafting in the mountain torrents. [SEP] And skiing, downhill and cross-country, has been greatly enhanced by the ultra-modern facilities installed for Calgary’s 1988 Winter Olympics. [SEP] Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba form the Prairie Provinces, sharing the same rugged climate. [SEP] The full meaning of Canada’s “wide open spaces” be

column1: About 150 km (90 miles) west of Whitehorse on the Alaska Highway, the entrance to this wilderness reserve is at Haines Junction. [SEP] The park’s St. Elias Mountain Range offers a challenge to climbers, including the highest peak in Canada, Mount Logan. [SEP] You’ll find moose, timber wolves, black bear, and grizzlies here. [SEP] For safety’s sake, check in at the park reception center and get maps and information on the hiking trails covering 240 km (144 miles) of challenging terrain. [SEP] The vast Kluane icefield system is made up of some 2,000 glaciers, and you can hike right to the rim of the spectacular Kaskawulsh Glacier from Kluane Lake on the eastern edge of the park. [SEP] Bird-watchers spot eagles, falcons, and hawks. [SEP] Fishermen
column3: for the trout, grayling, and lake salmon. [SEP] Northwest Territories

column1: Northwest Territories If you feel drawn by a rendezvous with the Midnight Sun, make for these immense lands covering one-third of Canada’s total surface, where, compared to the icy expanses inside the Arctic Circle, the tundra passes for lush meadowland. [SEP] The summer, when temperatures climb to a comfortable 21°C (70°F) in Mackenzie District, offers the blessed privilege of a dazzling explosion of wild flowers. [SEP] Beluga whales
column3: out to play around Baffin Island. [SEP] In autumn, the magical northern lights of the aurora borealis are at their most brilliant. [SEP] Yellowknife

column1: The Bug Bubble burst with the rise of chemical dyes in the 1870s. [SEP] With the failure of yet another mono-culture, the Spanish government felt constrained to help the Canarian economy. [SEP] In the mid-19th century, free port status was granted by royal decree to one port in each of the islands (two in Tenerife). [SEP] The lowering of duties and trade barriers at a time of considerable shipping expansion had the desired effect, and Santa Cruz de Tenerife and Las Palmas soon became two of the world’s busiest ports. [SEP] The most recent major crop to
column3: from the Canaries is bananas. [SEP] The variety is the dwarf banana, small and very tasty, and today demand actually outstrips production in some areas. [SEP] The first exports were made in the 1880s and the banana has continued to be a mainstay of the islands’ economy. [SEP] Despite some recent problems and concern for the future, it is hoped that bananas will continue to be an important Canarian crop alongside their other staples; tomatoes and potatoes. [SEP] In 1912, Cabildos (Island Councils) were created and given the responsibility for the social, political and economic administration of each island, and co-ordination with the Town Halls. [SEP] This led, in 1927, to the islands being divided into two provinces; Santa Cruz de Tenerife with the islands of Tenerife, La Palma, La Gomera a

column1: The Spanish Civil War The plot that sparked off the Spanish Civil War was hatched in the Canary Islands. [SEP] In 1936 a group of senior officers, discontented with the policies of the Spanish Republican Government, met in secret in the woods of La Esperanza on Tenerife. [SEP] They had
column3: to meet a fellow officer, Francisco Franco, whom the government had banished to the Canaries for subversive plotting. [SEP] From the Canaries, Franco took off for North Africa, the launching pad for the insurgent right-wing attack. [SEP] Three years later his armies had triumphed in a ruthless struggle that cost hundreds of thousands of Spanish lives. [SEP] The Canaries were not spared the horrors of the war (mass Republican executions took place in the aptly named Barranco del Infierno, the Gorge of Hell, on Tenerife), but on the whole the islands prospered during Franco’s period of dictatorship, which provided for added protection to their free-port status.

column1: Villages and groups of one kind or another dress according to chosen themes, with magnificent and often outrageous costumes that can take a whole year to put together. [SEP] Bands and dancers mingle with the elaborate floats. [SEP] Tourists are treated with good-natured humor, and many don masks and costumes to join in the fun. [SEP] The music and dancing continue until late, with parties everywhere. [SEP] Carnaval is biggest and best in Santa Cruz and Puerto de la Cruz on Tenerife and in Las Palmas on Gran Canaria, where it has all the razzmatazz of Rio’s Carnaval and the Mardi Gras of New Orleans. [SEP] Visitors
column3: from all over the world for these events, and hotels are often full, so book well ahead if you plan to visit at this time of year. [SEP] Corpus Christi

column1: lf of the 19th century. [SEP] Just across the road you can stop to pay a visit to the edge of the volcanic crater of Volcán de San Antonio and the mirador beyond it, (open daily 8am–6pm). [SEP] In an exposed, windy location this looks, considering the damage it did, exceedingly benign. [SEP] Just south of here are even more recent signs of volcanic activity; the volcano of Teneguía that erupted in 1971, fortunately without casualties. [SEP] These eruptions sent an ever-widening stream of molten lava rushing down the green hillside here and you can see it now, petrified and black, as the road runs right through the once deadly mass. [SEP] Surprisingly, plátanos (bananas) seem to take a liking to this environment, and can be seen thriving all around you. [SEP] Once down to sea level you will
column3: across the Playa de Zamora a small beach of jet-black sand squeezed in between the surrealistic lava fields. [SEP] A short distance away, next to the twin lighthouses — one old and one new — is a tiny fishermen’s cove with a stony beach that has a tiny restaurant, well, a shack really, that serves up the most delicious fresh fried fish (see page 139). [SEP] After that there is nothing of note, except of course the lava fields and views, until you rejoin the main road at Fuencaliente. [SEP] Heading back north towards Santa Cruz, a stop at the Cueva de Belmaco is in order. [SEP] Here, you will find the Parque Arqueológico de Belmaco (Archaeological Site of Belmaco). [SEP] The first stone engravings found in the Canary Islands were discovered here in the 18th century, and the ten natural cave

column1: features and a spectacular mirador in its own right. [SEP] This volcanic crater, almost a kilometer (more than a half mile) across, is green, fertile.and drops some 198 m (650 ft) down. [SEP] A scenic spiraling road leads to the top, where the Real Club de Golf enjoys such a picturesque location that even non-golfers are tempted to pick up a club. [SEP] The views from here take in the mountains, fertile valley and vast stretches of the coastline from Las Palmas to the distant south. [SEP] From the west of the island drive north from Agaete and then turn inland following the signs to Tejeda for a really pleasant, and not unduly difficult, mountain ascent. [SEP] The valleys here are wide and their slopes play host to some small farms; it is one of the few places in the islands where you will
column3: across farm animals. [SEP] Of interest, too, are the fantastic views across the ocean on a fine day to the snowcapped Mount Teide floating majestically above the clouds and the mountain peaks and lush valleys of Gran Canaria itself. [SEP] Before reaching Tejeda turn off to the village of Artenara, to the southwest, and what is undoubtedly the best restaurant view on the island. [SEP] The place in question is Méson de la Silla, not easy to spot, parallel to the main road. [SEP] A dark tunnel leads through the rock with no hint of what is to

column1: The North of the Island On an island so dominated by the works and creativity of one man, it would be inappropriate not to pay a visit to the Fundación César Manrique; Taro de Tahiche; Manrique lived here and, as you might have
column3: to expect, it is rather unusual. [SEP] Built in 1968, it is located over a river of lava formed from the eruptions between 1730 and 1736 and takes advantage, at its lowest point, of five volcanic bubbles to create the strange, but nonetheless impressive living space. [SEP] The geographic center of Lanzarote lies 9 km (51⁄2 miles) northwest of the capital at Mozaga, focal point of the island’s viniculture. [SEP] Here the late César Manrique designed and erected a huge white modern sculpture, Monumento al Campesino, dedicated to the peasant workers of the island.

column1: The geographic center of Lanzarote lies 9 km (51⁄2 miles) northwest of the capital at Mozaga, focal point of the island’s viniculture. [SEP] Here the late César Manrique designed and erected a huge white modern sculpture, Monumento al Campesino, dedicated to the peasant workers of the island. [SEP] A few miles north of La Santa, home to the Club La Santa a time-share development resort where athletes of the highest level
column3: for both training and relaxation, is the tiny village of Caleta de Famara. [SEP] It has windswept beaches with views of the daunting cliffs of the Famara Massif that lead up to the Mirador del Río and Graciosa island. [SEP] There is not much to do along this coastline except sunbathe and windsurf, but as the currents can be dangerous here, be sure to take care. [SEP] Teguise is a fine old town of cobbled streets and gracious mansions and was the island capital until 1852. [SEP] Now it is calm and quiet for six days of the week. [SEP] On Sundays a handicrafts market

column1: What to Buy Handicrafts. [SEP] The Mayan people have always made everything they needed, and their handicrafts, though often practical, make beautiful souvenirs. [SEP] Basketware made from sisal and other plant species found in the area is typically used to carry a range of goods; woven mats can also be found. [SEP] Hammocks
column3: in a bewildering range of quality, colors, and sizes; you’ll have your choice of a sencillo (single) or one to share with friends, such as a doble (double) or matrimonial (family-sized). [SEP] Weaving has also been a very important skill for the Mayans. [SEP] The fabric produced on personal looms in traditional patterns and colors is used in a variety of different products. [SEP] Sarapes, cotton or wool blankets, and rugs are popular, but you will also find the material made into jackets and hats.

column1: Entertainment Once the sun goes down, Cancún gears up. [SEP] There’s no shortage of places to go or things to do, and no need to take a long novel to fill those quiet moments — there just won’t be any. [SEP] Many people don’t take to their beds until they’ve seen the sun
column3: up. [SEP] If you choose to stay in Mujeres or Cozumel, things will be a bit more laid back. [SEP] The diving fraternity tends to enjoy low-key, less glamorous entertainment and relatively early nights before they head under the waves early the following day. [SEP] Before you head straight into the resort atmosphere of Cancún, check out what’s happening in your hotel. [SEP] Many have “Las Vegas style” floor shows, Mexican evenings with traditional folk music and dances, and clubs where you can take to the dance floor yourself.

column1: les built for the goddess of fertility Ix chel. [SEP] It was he who named the island. [SEP] Mujeres is only 8 km (5 miles) in length, less than a kilometer (1⁄2 mile) at its widest point, and split by inland lakes and bays. [SEP] One main road forms an ellipse, following the shape of the coastline. [SEP] Most ferries deposit you at the very northern tip of the island, on the main pier of the only town on Mujeres. [SEP] Craft shops and bars crowd onto the sidewalks and sandy streets. [SEP] The place bustles, especially when the ferries arrive. [SEP] As afternoon turns to evening and the day-trippers head back to Cancún, Isla Mujeres takes on a much quieter character. [SEP] The island has many loyal fans that return year after year for its particular atmosphere. [SEP] Many who choose to stay
column3: for the diving, which usually means low-key entertainment and early nights. [SEP] A few minutes’ walk north of town is the main beach, Playa Norte, also known as Coco Beach. [SEP] It has sheltered waters and fine sand, particularly suitable for children. [SEP] Coconut palms provide shade and a few pelicans fly overhead in search of a meal.

column1: jas (Quadrangle of the Nuns), given its name in the 16th century because it resembled a Spanish monastery or nunnery. [SEP] Its size — over 70 rooms — has caused archaeologists to postulate that it may have been a military academy, which expanded regularly throughout its history. [SEP] The western building has the most richly carved façade. [SEP] There are also numerous depictions of Mayan homes or nah, which have changed little since classical times and can still be found all across the countryside of Yucatán. [SEP] The eastern building has a statue of a dwarf dressed in a turtle shell placed in a position normally associated with the rulers of Mayan cities. [SEP] A serpent is entwined all along the upper façade around the statue. [SEP] From its upper levels the many buildings at the site
column3: clearly into view. [SEP] The quadrangle is the setting for the Uxmal Light and Sound Show, which takes place every evening. [SEP] South of the quadrangle, beyond a small ball court, the land rises to a higher level. [SEP] Here another group of buildings forms the main center of focus at the site. [SEP] The Casa de las Tortugas (Turtle House), so called because of numerous turtle motifs adorning it, is found immediately on the right. [SEP] Beside, and totally dwarfing it, lies the Palacio del Gobernador (Governor’s Palace) with an imposing 100-m- (320-ft-) long façade. [SEP] The building was erected in the 11th century for the ruler of the city, Halach Huinic (the true man), and consists of a central building flanked by two smaller wings. [SEP] The frieze of Chaac masks is one of the most or

column1: What to Do Most visitors to China
column3: to see the nation’s many excellent historic and cultural sites, including the imperial treasures. [SEP] But there is much else of interest in this vast land to make the journey truly enjoyable. [SEP] You will of course want to bring home at least a few souvenirs, and you will have opportunities to attend presentations of an incredible range of performing arts. [SEP] It will not be difficult to fill your moments of leisure with memorable activities that will make your trip last well after you return home. [SEP] Shopping

column1: Ethnic novelties. [SEP] Artisans from China’s ethnic minority groups produce a good share of exotica: ornaments and figurines, ceremonial knives and swords, skullcaps and other headgear, colorful dresses and shirts, and shaggy sheepskin coats. [SEP] Fans. [SEP] One factory in Hangzhou alone manufactures 10 million fans per year, most of them for export. [SEP] They
column3: in several hundred varieties, but the best known folding fans are made of fragrant sandalwood or black paper. [SEP] Figurines. [SEP] Ceramic polychrome figurines of historic or legendary personages are popular, as are little animals, with the panda the most sought after.

column1: Seals. [SEP] These ink stamps (also called “chops”) are the traditional Chinese substitute for handwritten signatures. [SEP] You can have one carved just for you, with your name incised — perhaps in ancient Chinese block characters — in soapstone, plastic, jade, or ivory. [SEP] Souvenirs. [SEP] In any local department store or street market you’re likely to
column3: across some very Chinese inspirations: acupuncture charts and dolls, those ubiquitous thermos flasks, tea mugs with lids, padded jackets, posters, and so on. [SEP] Tea. [SEP] A collection of Chinese teas (black, green, semi-fermented, and flower-petal) makes an inexpensive, useful, and long-lasting souvenir. [SEP] Tea is frequently packaged in special, artistically decorated containers.

column1: ple of Heaven Park, is the biggest of Beijing’s parks, celebrated for its assembly of thrilling 15th-century architecture. [SEP] The highlight is the circular, blue tile-roofed Hall of Prayer for Good Harvest (Qiniandian). [SEP] This marvel of geometry, art, and engineering, built without a single nail, measures 371⁄2 m (123 ft) to the gilded orb on its topmost roof. [SEP] In 1889 the masterpiece was struck by lightning and burned almost to the ground. [SEP] Fortunately, the ruin was quickly restored to its original, resplendent state. [SEP] The emperor was carried here in a procession in the first lunar month of each year to pray for a bountiful harvest. [SEP] The floor plan of the hall provides the key to the building’s function. [SEP] The four central columns represent the seasons; then
column3: two concentric rings of 12 columns each, representing the months and the dozen two-hour periods into which the day was divided; and 28 hardwood pillars symbolize the constellations. [SEP] Although tourists can no longer enter this monument, its colorful interiors can still be glimpsed from outside. [SEP] Other attractions at the park include the Round Altar (Haunqiutan) and Echo Wall, where whispered secrets ricochet and are mysteriously magnified, crossing an immense courtyard, without benefit of modern technology.

column1: The first elements of the wall system were built more than 2,000 years ago, but the expansion and consolidation of the project near Beijing began under the Ming Dynasty in the 14th century. [SEP] The serpentine stone bulwark and elevated highway became Wanlichangcheng — “The Wall Ten Thousand Li Long” (about 6,000 km/3,700 miles). [SEP] The restored section of the wall at Badaling, undulating up the unexpectedly steep hillsides, can be a test of a tourist’s endurance. [SEP] It is far steeper and more formidable than it looks in any tourist brochure. [SEP] Out of breath, many visitors exchange sympathetic smiles along the way as they ascend to one or another of the towers. [SEP] If you walk far enough west, you
column3: upon unrestored sections of the wall at the edge of the Gobi Desert. [SEP] The Badaling section is often overcrowded these days. [SEP] Two other sections now provide relatively easy access to tourists: the Great Wall at Mutianyu, as beautiful as the section at Badaling but a little less steep, and the Great Wall at Simatai, more distant from Beijing than other sections but virtually unrestored. [SEP] Simatai is the least crowded and most original of the Great Wall sites. [SEP] Although it too has a cable-car concession, Simatai bills itself as “the most dangerous section of the Great Wall.”

column1: , and passenger ships. [SEP] On the far side of the river, fragrant forests climb the slopes of Yuelu Hill, a favorite escape from the subtropical heat of the city in summer. [SEP] One of the evergreen trees in the mountainside Lushan Temple is more than 1,700 years old. [SEP] The Qing Dynasty pavilion on top (Yunlugong) affords a fine panorama. [SEP] For most tourists the prime attraction of the region is found in the northeast part of town: the Hunan Provincial Museum, with its renowned relics of the Han Dynasty, including silks, ceramics, and lacquerware of unbelievable sophistication, as well as alluring figurines and musical instruments. [SEP] All these artifacts survived because they were buried in coffins within coffins in subterranean royal tombs. [SEP] These beautiful wooden boxes
column3: from the royal graves at Mawangdui, as does the museum’s show-stopper: the remarkably well-preserved silk-wrapped mummy of the Marquis of Dai’s wife, Tohou, who died at age 50 in 186 b.c. Nearly 2,200 years later, her hair is still on her head and her expression is unchanged from the moment of her last breath. [SEP] Tourists in Changsha are sometimes taken to visit the local embroidery factory, where Hunan’s handicraft tradition has flourished for 2,000 years. [SEP] Staff artists paint original designs, usually of landscapes, animals, birds, or flowers, which the artisans reproduce stitch by microscopic stitch in colorful silk. [SEP] The workers here are proudest of the double-faced embroidery, with a different picture on each side.

column1: Dunhuang (Tunhuang) It used to take 24 hours by train, plus a cruel two- or three-hour bus or jeep journey, to reach the sleepy desert town of Dunhuang, in Gansu province. [SEP] Now it’s an easy airplane ride from Xi’an. [SEP] Dunhuang has
column3: a long way since the days when the Silk Road camel trains stopped here. [SEP] Camels still work in and around Dunhuang, pulling plows or transporting cargo. [SEP] If you’ve just

column1: Mogao Caves In spite of the difficulties, tourists still head for this 2,000-year-old town to see China’s most magnificent ancient murals and painted statues. [SEP] Since you’ve
column3: this far, they’re worth another 25 km (15 miles). [SEP] The Mogao Caves, hewn from a desert cliffside, tell the story of the great flowering of Buddhist art in China. [SEP] Begun in the fourth century, they were created in fits and starts over the next thousand years. [SEP] Statistics aren’t everything, but consider that there are 45,000 sq m (484,000 sq ft) of mural paintings. [SEP] They cover the walls and ceilings with brightly colored pictures of men and gods and speculations about eternity. [SEP] And in the same caves stand more than 2,000 painted sculptures, realistic or fantastic. [SEP] Of the several hundred grottoes still intact, only a few dozen are open to the public. [SEP] And even these are kept locked so that visits can be supervised. [SEP] The outer walls of the caves have be

column1: The capital of the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, Hohhot is a sprawling, booming city with a metropolitan population of more than one million. [SEP] The center of town looks to the future with new official buildings, housing blocks, and wide avenues, but the traffic evokes nostalgia with its parade of donkey carts, ox carts, pony carts, and farm tractors, plus the usual proliferation of bicycles. [SEP] It might
column3: as a surprise that Mongolians are only a small minority here. [SEP] Most of the residents of Hohhot are Han (ethnic Chinese), and Inner Mongolia’s close connection with China dates back several centuries. [SEP] For tourists in search of the exotic, though, Hohhot and vicinity offer many opportunities to make contact with Mongolian traditions. [SEP] You can drink butter tea with millet and sleep in a yurt, a felt-covered circular tent. [SEP] A quite unexpected feature of Hohhot is its modern racecourse. [SEP] Under the sky-blue domes of the reviewing stand, visitors are often treated to a Mongolian “rodeo” of racing and trick riding and perhaps a procession of two-humped camels. [SEP] Another lively spot is Xinhua Square, where half the town seems to exercise and play before work, returning

column1: of Chinese classics. [SEP] You will find one pinnacle in the image of an “Elephant on a Stone Terrace” and another like a “Rhinoceros Looking at the Moon.” [SEP] At one point in the maze you must squeeze through the Narrowest Pass; doing so, according to Sani legend, adds ten years to your life. [SEP] From Peak Viewing Pavilion, the highest point in the Stone Forest, there’s a comprehensive view of this great thicket of jagged rocks thrusting skyward. [SEP] The biggest open space in the Stone Forest, a lawn surrounded by cherry trees, is the site of a Sani festival each June. [SEP] For 48 continuous hours, the tribesmen devote themselves to singing and dancing, wrestling matches, bullfights (actually, water buffalo fighting each other), feasting, and romancing. [SEP] Many of the celebrants
column3: from Five Tree Village (Wukeshu), across Shilin Lake from the hotel. [SEP] This community of several thousand Sani residents shelters water buffalo, pigs, goats, and dogs. [SEP] The Sani themselves live in thatched-roof, mud-and-wattle houses. [SEP] Those who stay the night in the Stone Forest are usually entertained with a Sani folklore show. [SEP] Among the instruments in the orchestra are flutes, zithers, and a giant banjo with a hollow bottom. [SEP] Women dancers wear red, white, and black conical hats, while the men sport floppy black turbans. [SEP] Through song and mime they recount the legends that link their people to the otherworldly presence of the Stone Forest.

column1: Around Nanjing Chinese pilgrims of all political persuasions
column3: from many countries to honor the founder of the Chinese Republic at the Mausoleum of Dr. Sun Yat-sen (Zhongshanling), in the Purple Hills east of Nanjing. [SEP] The hillside complex roofed with blue tiles, completed in 1929, could scarcely be more grandiose. [SEP] Following a long winding avenue planted with plane trees, you continue up the 392 granite steps of the ceremonial staircase to the actual memorial hall. [SEP] There are statues of Dr. Sun standing, sitting (by a French sculptor, Paul Landowski), and recumbent above the vault itself. [SEP] On the ceiling is a mosaic version of the Nationalist (Guomindang) flag, a white star on a blue background. [SEP] Dr. Sun often roamed these hills during his Nanjing years. [SEP] It was his own wish that he be buried here, although he could never

column1: Guitars, the rhythm of castanets and drumming heels, and taut, anguished songs — that’s flamenco. [SEP] You’ll be left breathless by these songs and dances from Andalusia. [SEP] There are two distinct forms of flamenco: the cante jondo (deep song) is an outpouring of intense, soul-searching emotions. [SEP] The agonized songs, heavy with the wail of Arabia,
column3: from deep within the singer, while the dances are formal and sombre. [SEP] Cante jondo is seldom heard outside Andalusia and Madrid, except on recordings. [SEP] Not so the cante chico (light song), a more animated version performed in tablaos (floor shows) on the Costa Blanca. [SEP] With a little luck, you may even see flamenco performed by a top Spanish dance company touring on behalf of the Ministry of Information and Tourism’s Festivales de España. [SEP] Although the songs may express something of the cante jondo’s desolation, the dancing is very different. [SEP] The fandango, tango, farruca, and zambra are performed to the staccato rhythm of palmadas (hand-clapping), pitos (finger-snapping), the zapateado of fiercely drumming heels, and the fiery compulsion of the castanets.

column1: Eating Out Far more interesting than the so-called international cuisine, the hearty local dishes are worth seeking out: ingredients
column3: fresh from the sea or the farm and are served with a wide choice of the region’s excellent vegetables. [SEP] Most tourist hotels and restaurants specialize in caution, with menus guaranteed to cause neither rapture nor complaints. [SEP] Ask around and find out where Spaniards and resident expatriates eat. [SEP] Soups and Stews

column1: Tour operators offer any number of excursions, some more esoteric than others, with brochures and booking facilities available through your hotel or a local travel agent. [SEP] Another form of organized entertainment, amusement parks, are discussed below in the section for families with young children. [SEP] Bullfights: Andalucía is famed for its bullfighting traditions, and has two, Sevilla and Córdoba, of the seven first-class Plaza de Toros (bullrings) in Spain. [SEP] The provincial capitals of Almería, Granada, Huelva, Jaén, and Málaga as well as Algeciras and El Puerto de Santa María are second-class rings. [SEP] All others, including those of the resort towns along the Costa del Sol,
column3: into the third class category. [SEP] The two main events are a Corrida de Toros, where fully qualified matadors fight fully-grown — at least 4 year old — toros (bulls), and Novilladas, where novilleros (novice matadors) fight novillos (immature bulls). [SEP] As a rule of thumb, the better events are held in the better plazas, particularly during the ferías (holiday fairs) held in the major cities. [SEP] Equally true is the fact that most of the events held in the resort towns are mainly for the benefit of tourists, and are of lesser quality. [SEP] They are not generally less expensive, though; small rings mean fewer seats, which often equates to higher prices. [SEP] Contrary to popular opinion, bullfights are not held every Sunday in each city. [SEP] In fact, outside of the ferías — when th

column1: But Marbella has its historic side, too. [SEP] In fact, its history dates back some 1,600 years, even though most of what can be seen, in the town at least, dates from the time of the Catholic Monarchs and later. [SEP] North of the main road, the Casco Antiguo (Old Town) provides an intriguing glimpse of the past that has been cleverly integrated to cater to modern visitors. [SEP] First, sit at a café table in the Plaza de los Naranjos (Square of the Orange Trees), where you can admire the noble 16th-century façade of the Casa Consistorial (Town Hall) and soak up the atmosphere. [SEP] Then wander through the maze of narrow, twisting streets where the whitewashed walls are decorated with colorful baskets of flowers. [SEP] As you explore the neighborhood, you’ll
column3: across the historic parish church with its landmark bell tower, and the convents of La Trinidad and San Francisco (it is said that Miguel de Cervantes, creator of the famous Don Quixote, lodged at the latter). [SEP] Uphill from the church lie the crumbling walls of the Moorish castillo. [SEP] Scattered throughout this area also are an eclectic array of shops and galleries. [SEP] Other places of interest in Marbella are the Bonsai Museum, the only one in Spain and one of the best in the world, and the Museum of Spanish Contemporary Engravings. [SEP] Housed in a structure important in its own right, the latter is the first of its kind in Spain and has works by Picasso, Miró, Tapies, and other such famous artists.

column1: onsidered the best preserved Moorish baths in Europe. [SEP] The museum has interesting exhibits on Gibraltar’s history. [SEP] Of interest, too, is Nelson’s Anchorage, where Admiral Nelson’s body is said to have been brought in a barrel of rum after the Battle of Trafalgar on 21 October 1805, and the nearby 100-ton Victorian super-gun, the largest gun of its type in the world. [SEP] Main Street ends at the Referendum Gates. [SEP] Beyond lies the cable-car station, where you can take a trip to the top of the Rock with a stop halfway to visit the Apes’ Den. [SEP] The tail-less Barbary apes that inhabit the Rock are natives of North Africa, descended from monkeys brought over by sailors as pets and ships’ mascots. [SEP] Legend has it that if the apes ever leave the Rock, then British rule will
column3: to an end. [SEP] When the apes’ population declined significantly during World War II, Winston Churchill himself was worried, and the monkeys have been on special rations ever since. [SEP] The views from the summit 426 m (396 ft) up are spectacular, particularly across the strait to Morocco, along the coast toward Estepona, and down the sheer east face of the Rock to the water holding areas (for desalination) and the beaches of Sandy Bay, Catalan Bay, and Eastern Beach. [SEP] Whether you’re traveling in your own car or in an official taxi or minivan, don’t leave Gibraltar without taking a tour of the Upper Rock Nature Reserve area. [SEP] On the way up note the yellow patches and their accompanying metal rings; these were used when manually hauling the heavy cannons up the Rock. [SEP] Also o

column1: Along the road from Almuñécar, pretty villas with spectacular coastal views dot the hillsides until, all of a sudden, the scenery changes dramatically. [SEP] As the coast flattens out, a town of whitewashed houses atop a rocky, cone-shaped hill
column3: s into view. [SEP] Called Salobreña, it makes for an impressive sight. [SEP] A Moorish castle, beautifully restored, stands isolated at the heart of the village. [SEP] Salobreña stands as the gateway to the agriculturally rich vega (plain) of the thriving port city of Motril. [SEP] Sugarcane, the source of the greenery, flourishes here. [SEP] The sugar refineries in the area have earned the town its nickname — Little Cuba. [SEP] Like that country, Motril is known for its rum, although its residents are crafty enough to make just about enough for local consumption, and no more. [SEP] Motril and Salobreña have their own extensive beaches and there are many more to

column1: Pottery and Ceramics It’s not surprising, given the importance of ceramics and pottery throughout Crete’s history, that it is still a significant industry. [SEP] Pieces
column3: as small as a ring holder or olive bowl to huge garden pieces that would have to be shipped back home. [SEP] Both unglazed and ceramic styles are available; most notable of these is the bright blue glaze of Chaniá ceramics. [SEP] Traditional designs abound, including marine themes, Minoan designs, and Classical Greek imagery. [SEP] Modern free-form pieces can also be found, particularly in Chaniá where there are galleries stocked by avant-garde potters. [SEP] At Margerítes you can watch the potters at work and buy from their workshops. [SEP] Children’s Crete

column1: Inland from Ágios Nikólaos are three attractions that make an enjoyable morning or afternoon sightseeing. [SEP] Head out towards the village of Kritsá 12 km (7 miles) from town. [SEP] Before you reach the village itself you’ll find a beautiful Byzantine chapel on your right. [SEP] Panagía Kerá was built in the 13th century and decorated with superb frescoes of the 14th and 15th centuries. [SEP] You’ll need time to take in every detail of the interior and the simple lines of the exterior. [SEP] Resume your journey toward Kritsá, but don’t visit the village yet. [SEP] Follow signs to Lató, the remains of a Dorian city (7th–3rd centuries b.c.) scattered around two scrub-covered hilltops to the north. [SEP] The blocks of strong stone don’t
column3: close to rivaling the fine fresco-covered walls of Minoan settlements, yet there is a satisfaction in both location and form when you climb among the remains of Lató. [SEP] There are also wonderful views down to the coast from here. [SEP] Finally you can allow yourself to head into Kritsá, perhaps to take some well-earned refreshment. [SEP] This ‘traditional’ village is perhaps overly touristy for some but it is still very much lived-in and extremely well-kept, with brilliant whitewashed walls accented by brightly painted windowframes and charming potted plants. [SEP] You’ll find good tavernas around the old village square — look for the huge plane tree. [SEP] Always famed for its carpet weaving and textiles, you’ll see examples hanging from walls and shop doorways in the narrow streets. [S

column1: The monastery has many treasures within its church —  Panagiá Akrotirianí — and museum. [SEP] Sixty-one scenes from the Greek prayer Lord, Thou Art Great by renowned icon painter Ioánnis Kornáros (1770) are among the highlights, along with jewel-encrusted vestments and reliquaries of precious metals. [SEP] You can visit the simple monks’ cells on the first floor and explore the old flour mill which once brought in
column3: to the order. [SEP] Today the farmland owned by the monastery produces organic olive oil considered some of the best on Crete. [SEP] You can buy it at the small gift shop along with icons and religious books. [SEP] Northeast of Toploú is one of Crete’s natural wonders. [SEP] Amid this arid landscape an oasis of verdant palms

column1: és were where Ottomans used to socialize over dark thick coffee and communal narghiles (bubble pipes). [SEP] Today you can spend time over a drink or excellent fish dinner. [SEP] The maze of narrow streets behind the old harbor forms the core of the old town. [SEP] Most are pedestrian-only, inviting you to take an exploratory stroll. [SEP] At every turn there is something to see; most obvious will be the wealth of shopping opportunities at eye level. [SEP] Craft and jewelry stores create tempting displays, and cotton clothing is swathed across every wall. [SEP] But don’t neglect to look behind the wares to see Venetian stone lintels above, or to catch site of ornate Ottoman balconies and pretty wooden window frames dressed with bougainvillaea or honeysuckle. [SEP] At night the streets here
column3: alive with shoppers and revelers, and there are excellent restaurants in some of the old buildings. [SEP] If you exit the harbor from the southwest you can cross busy Odós Arkadíou to traffic-free Odós Petiháki. [SEP] On your left is the Venetian Loggia built in 1600. [SEP] Until recently it was sadly neglected but it has risen like a phoenix from the ashes and now performs the role of an up-market gallery where you can buy excellent copies of museum pieces. [SEP] Walk down Petiháki to find the Rimondi Fountain. [SEP] Built in the 1620s its once fine carvings have taken on an aged patina and it looks strangely out of place among the bright Internet cafés now replacing traditional tavernas in this bustling square.

column1: own of Villena, the farthest point from Alicante (64 km/39 miles away) on this tour. [SEP] The castle here, noted for its double walls and high, eight-turreted tower rarely found south of Madrid, also has national monument status. [SEP] Villena’s castle was originally built by Moors, though considerable additions were made in the 15th century. [SEP] The town’s priceless Bronze Age treasure, discovered in a clay jar in the riverbed, is exhibited in the Ayuntamiento (Town Hall). [SEP] The gold jewellery and objects attest to the artistry of Villena’s early inhabitants. [SEP] Swing south from Villena along the N-330 to Sax, site of the Roman town of Saxum. [SEP] The towers of the original Roman castle, which has been fully restored, are still a look-out point. [SEP] Back on the N-330 you soon
column3: to Petrel’s Moorish castle, reputed to have fabulous treasure buried in its grounds. [SEP] Unrestored medieval fortresses are found along the C-3212 road to Elda, and beyond, at Monóvar. [SEP] Elda itself is noted for excellent wine and lace-making. [SEP] The town was the birthplace of the famous writer, José Martínez Ruiz, better known as Azorín. [SEP] From Elda, follow the signs to Novelda to find yet another Moorish castle set high on a hill. [SEP] This one is the Castillo de la Mola, erected on the site of a Roman fort. [SEP] It has an unusual triangular tower dating from the 13th century. [SEP] Right next to it you’ll see a strange structure reminiscent of Gaudí’s still unfinished Templo de la Sagrada Familia in Barcelona.

column1: Benidorm With twin, crescent-moon beaches, 7 km (4 miles) of golden sands, and an outstanding climate, Benidorm is one of Spain’s most popular resorts. [SEP] But it wasn’t always so. [SEP] Despite efforts over a hundred years ago by a local entrepreneur, who hoped to bring holiday-makers to the area by a regular stage coach service, large-scale tourism didn’t
column3: to Benidorm until the early 1960s. [SEP] Since then, a mass of apartment blocks and hotels has sprung up and the town has be

column1: The Vinalopó River, spanned by a bridge here, supplies the water that is still carried to the horts in canals dug by the Moors. [SEP] A short distance from the palace toward the city centre, you
column3: upon the Ayuntamiento (Town Hall), with its fine Renaissance façade and Gothic door. [SEP] Stand back for a good look at the 14th-century Torre del Concejo, a former watchtower. [SEP] The quaint carved figures of Calendura and Calendureta ring the hours and quarter hours, as they have done since 1759. [SEP] Crevillente

column1: Before you leave the sanctuary, visit the Capilla Mayor (Main Chapel). [SEP] The strangest of the cathedral’s treasures is contained in an urn here — the heart of Alfonso the Wise, bequeathed to Murcia by the 13th-century king long before his death. [SEP] Go out of the cathedral on the north side and walk across Plaza Hernandez Amores to the cool and classy Calle de la Trapería (Street of Secondhand Merchants). [SEP] But don’t look for bargains here; the name of this pedestrian thoroughfare belies the elegance of its shops. [SEP] At the north end you
column3: upon the Casino (a private club, not a gambling establishment), with spirited turn-of-the century decor. [SEP] The entrance hall, an exact copy of the Hall of Ambassadors in Seville’s Alcázar, and the ladies’ lavatory — with its ceiling of cherubs — are the most magnificent rooms. [SEP] (Don’t forget a small tip to the steward who shows you around.) [SEP] During the Casino’s heyday, the pedestrian Calle de la Platería (Street of Silversmiths), at right angles to the Trapería, was full of practising craftsmen. [SEP] Flower stalls in the Plaza de las Flores are open every morning. [SEP] After 11:00 a.m., vendors tend to retreat into nearby shops and bars, particularly in hot weather.

column1: nd a few plumbing parts. [SEP] But there are plenty of things for dollar-wielding visitors to buy now that private enterprise is permitted on a limited scale. [SEP] Tops on most people’s lists are Cuba’s greatest achievements (not including the national health care system): cigars, rum, and music. [SEP] There is also an excellent selection of handicrafts available at excellent prices in towns and resorts frequented by tourists. [SEP] Tourist markets are now thriving in Cuba’s major centers, even if much of what you’ll find is related to Che Guevara — berets, T-shirts bearing his countenance, and dolls, among many other “revolutionary” items. [SEP] As for essentials, hotel and dollar shops carry mineral water, soap, shampoo, and toothpaste, but many medicinal or cosmetic staples are hard to
column3: by; it’s still best to bring all you need from home. [SEP] Tiendas Panamericanas are well stocked dollar stores, but probably the most impressive dollar store in all Cuba is the Harris Bros. [SEP] Company, a multistory (it’s got an escalator!) enterprise near the landmark Art Deco Bacardí building and the capitol. [SEP] Cuban cities are now an uneasy mix of sad peso stores and bright dollar shops, with an influx of goods most Cubans can only dream about (indeed, you’ll see large crowds of people peering dreamily into shop windows). [SEP] The uneven divide between communist ideals and materialist longings is one of the great contradictions in contemporary Cuba. [SEP] Browsing along shopping streets proves endlessly fascinating, though, and provides profound insights into Cuba’s arcane econom

column1: The streets of Havana are a living museum of chrome-finned wondercars imported during Detroit’s heyday, but several that once belonged to pivotal Cuban figures — among them a 1918 Ford truck used by Fidel’s father and Che’s 1960 Chevrolet Bel Air — are lined up in the Museo de Autos Antiguos (Calle Oficios, 13). [SEP] Continuing west along Calle Oficios, you’ll
