column3: to a splendidly restored square, Plaza de San Francisco, with upscale shops, restaurants, and the imposing 18th-century Iglesia y Convento de San Francisco de Asís. [SEP] The convent contains a museum with Spanish treasures, and you can climb the belltower for spectacular views of Old Havana. [SEP] Concerts are frequently held here. [SEP] Nearby, you’ll find several impeccable colonial-era houses with brilliantly colored façades. [SEP] Plaza Vieja

column1: In the same year, the government acquired the Museo de Artes Decorativas, at Calle 17 between Calles D and E. Each room in this grand 19th-century villa is furnished in a particular style: English Chippendale, Chinese, baroque, or Art Deco in the fabulous bathroom. [SEP] Vedado’s top sight, though, is the Cementerio de Cristóbal Colón (Columbus Cemetery). [SEP] Massive marble mausoleums line the principal avenues of the cemetery, a vast city of the dead established in the late 1800s. [SEP] Cubans
column3: to pray and place flowers at the tomb of La Milagrosa (“The Miracle Worker”), who helps people in need. [SEP] It is said that she was buried with her infant at her feet, but when their bodies were exhumed, the child was found cradled in her arms. [SEP] Plaza de la Revolución

column1: Cayo Largo and the Isle of Youth The two main islands in the Archipiélago de los Canarreos, south of western Cuba, could not be more different. [SEP] Cayo Largo is a tourist enclave where visitors are never more than a few yards from sugar-white sands. [SEP] Yet it’s an antiseptic place, devoid of any Cubans except those who work there. [SEP] By contrast, the Isle of Youth sees virtually no tourists except those at the rather isolated Hotel El Colony (on the small island’s southwestern tip), who
column3: exclusively for the superb diving at a nearby beach. [SEP] Cayo Largo, an island 25 km (15.5 miles) long and the most easterly of the Archipiélago de los Canarreos, might be your Caribbean paradise — if all you’re looking for is a dazzling white beach and clear blue seas. [SEP] Other than the miles of beaches, there’s not much else of consequence here except mangrove, scrub, and half a dozen comfortable hotels with a full program of entertainment and watersports. [SEP] Turtles nest in the sand at one end of the island. [SEP] At the other you can go sailing, diving, or deep-sea fishing or take a boat trip to Playa Sirena, an incomparable strip of sand a 10-minute boat ride away, where lobster lunches are available. [SEP] Cayo Largo, with its captive tourist audience, is considerably more exp

column1: includes crocodiles, manatees, and numerous species of birds. [SEP] Frankly, though, you are unlikely to see any interesting wildlife unless you take a guided bird-watching trip from Playa Larga. [SEP] You can see penned reptiles at the crocodile farm at La Boca, a popular tourist site where you can pose with a baby croc and taste crocodile steak. [SEP] A more appealing prospect is picturesque Guamá, a half-hour boat ride from La Boca along an artificial channel and then across the vast Laguna del Tesoro (Treasure Lake). [SEP] Legend has it that the Indians dumped their jewels into the water rather than surrender them to Spanish conquistadores. [SEP] Guamá is a group of tiny islands connected by wooden bridges. [SEP] A few visitors stay in the thatched cabañas (see page 131), but most just
column3: to wander along the boardwalk, greet the ducks and egrets, and have a meal. [SEP] The peninsula is best known, however, for its bloody role in clandestine political warfare. [SEP] South of La Boca you soon

[SEP] Legend has it that the Indians dumped their jewels into the water rather than surrender them to Spanish conquistadores. [SEP] Guamá is a group of tiny islands connected by wooden bridges. column1: h-caste Hindu origin, ruled in the Kathmandu Valley from about a.d. 330 to 700. [SEP] King Manadeva I (a.d. 462–505) shook off the domination of the India Gupta emperors and extended his kingdom from the Kosi River in the east to the Gandaki River in the west and from the Terai to the Himalayan passes. [SEP] A great king of this line, Amsuvarna (609–621), married his daughter Bhrikuti to the ruler of Tibet, Srongtsen Gampo. [SEP] In 640, Bhrikuti and her Chinese co-wife converted Srongtsen Gampo to Buddhism. [SEP] Bhrikuti is venerated as the “Green Tara” and the Chinese wife as the “White Tara.” [SEP] Their images are prominent in Nepalese Buddhist art. [SEP] Commercial and cultural links with Tibet, and through Tibet with China, were strengthened at this time. [SEP] More reliable records
column3: with the next major dynasty, the Malla, who were established in about 1200 by the strongman Ari Malla. [SEP] The Malla came to Nepal in the first of several waves of Hindu fugitives from the 11th-century Muslim invasion of northern India. [SEP] Many of the refugees were nobles of the Chetri warrior caste from Rajasthan; forging new feudal states in Nepal, they were responsible for reinforcing Hinduism at the expense of Buddhism. [SEP] The Kathmandu Valley itself was raided in 1336 by the Muslim Sultan of Bengal. [SEP] In seven days he destroyed both Hindu and Buddhist temples and statues, including Swayambhunath and Pashupatinath. [SEP] These great shrines were later rebuilt and expanded into their present magnificence. [SEP] The Malla period saw completion of Nepal’s most important palaces

column1: On the Trail Trekking isn’t mountain climbing, but it also isn’t just a stroll in the park. [SEP] It’s walking, with lots of uphills and downhills. [SEP] Almost anyone can go trekking, though a trek is definitely more enjoyable if you’re reasonably fit. [SEP] Sure there are lots of athletes on the trail who seem to be here merely for the challenge, but you’ll also
column3: across groups of the less physically fit, including school groups from the international school in Kathmandu and organized senior citizens’ treks, going happily along at their own pace. [SEP] As you hike, whether with a fully loaded backpack or just a light daypack, you can’t help marveling at the burdens that porters carry in their dokos (baskets). [SEP] Everything not made or grown in the villages has to he packed in on the backs of wiry, barefoot porters, who carry loads of as much as 60 kg (130 pounds). [SEP] Even more amazing is the fact that these baskets have no shoulder straps but only tump lines (forehead straps). [SEP] You may notice that going downhill, porters take short steps on the balls of their feet with their knees bent. [SEP] Do the same and you’ll avoid the common complai

column1: White-Water Rafting For heart-in-the-mouth thrills it is hard to beat white-water rafting on the tumultuous snow-fed rivers of Nepal. [SEP] Although trekking is still the favored outdoor adventure here, rafting is a close second. [SEP] Many rafting enthusiasts
column3: specifically to paddle this country’s challenging waters, which roar through some of the world’s deepest gorges. [SEP] The knowledge that even the best rafters sometimes capsize in these currents keeps the adrenaline flowing as fast as the river. [SEP] Although there are some easy floats on the lowland rivers, the majority of rafting in Nepal is on Class III through Class V waters, not ideal for neophytes. [SEP] However, plenty of first-timers do get out on the water during their stay in Nepal. [SEP] Rafts usually carry six passengers plus two guides, and the typical rafting trip includes nights spent camping on the riverbank, with the rafting crew setting up camp and preparing all the meals. [SEP] Rafters spend a few hours before lunch riding the rapids and enjoying the spectacular scenery

column1: y of Hanuman Dhoka Palace. [SEP] The palace, which now serves primarily as a museum, takes its name from the red-cloaked figure of the monkey god Hanuman that stands to the left of the main palace entrance. [SEP] This stone statue was erected in 1672 and stands atop a squat pillar. [SEP] The statue’s face is entirely obscured by red paste that is smeared on by worshippers. [SEP] Tour guides say the red paste is to spare Hanuman the sight of the goings-on — more acrobatic than erotic — carved on the struts of the small Jaganath Temple opposite. [SEP] When this bit of mythology is related, it immediately sends tour groups trotting across to see what is forbidden to the monkey god. [SEP] Some say the carvings are there for protection, because the goddess of lightning is a virgin who would not
column3: near anything so shocking. [SEP] The erotica is probably best explained, however, along with Nepal’s ubiquitous Shiva lingams (phalluses) and the female yoni symbols, as an expression of the creative energy in male-female relations and the pleasure principles of Tantrism. [SEP] In the palace wall beyond the Hanuman statue and protected by a wooden fence is a poem etched in stone in 15 languages dated 14 January 1664. [SEP] It is attributed to King Pratap Malla, reputed to be a great linguist.

column1: int, continuing to Thahiti Tole, where there is another small stupa, you can walk north to the main intersection of Thamel, Kathmandu’s lively, fast-spreading center for budget-conscious tourists. [SEP] Guest houses, restaurants, curio vendors, rug shops, trekking agencies, bicycle and motorcycle rental stands, and bookshops line the way. [SEP] Some guest houses have pleasant gardens, and most are clean and quite inexpensive, though in recent years more expensive hotels have also opened in this neighborhood. [SEP] Many low-budget guest houses have bulletin boards where trekkers leave messages for friends or advertise for trekking companions. [SEP] From Thamel’s center you can return to your starting point by heading right, or east, to a roundabout. [SEP] Back in the modern part of town you
column3: to the Kaiser Library. [SEP] This has nothing to do with the German emperors, but was built by Field-Marshal Kaiser (a distortion of the Nepali name Kesar) Shumshere Rana. [SEP] The tall trees surrounding this building, which also houses part of the Ministry of Education, are the daytime roost of a colony of large fruit bats that trade places at dusk with flocks of crows. [SEP] Inside the library there are old photos of assorted Ranas, smartly dressed in tweed suits, neckties, and polished boots, posing atop the huge rhinos and tigers they’ve slain. [SEP] The royal family lives in the modern Narayanhiti Palace across the street, behind flagpoles bearing the world’s only non-rectangular national flag. [SEP] (Nepal’s is made of two superimposed triangular pennants with sun and moon emblems.)

column1: Leaving the square on the lane that begins at the back of the Bhimsen Temple and following the street around to the right will bring you to the Golden Temple, or Kwa Bahal, a Buddhist monastery founded in the 11th century. [SEP] Two painted lions mark the entrance. [SEP] Inside, the monastery surrounds a sunken courtyard with an exquisite golden shrine in the center, backed by a pagoda temple decorated with episodes from the life of Buddha. [SEP] Flanking the steps leading to the courtyard and standing on statues of tortoises are two bronze elephants with praying riders on their backs. [SEP] On the upturned roof corners of the shimmering golden shrine stand bronze birds. [SEP] From the Golden Temple, continue descending the narrow lane and you will
column3: to temple complex dominated by a five-tiered pagoda, the Kumbheshwar Temple, which is dedicated to Shiva and dates to 1392. [SEP] Two ponds in the temple compound are said to be fed by waters from the holy Gosainkund Lake high in the Himalayas. [SEP] During summer, thousands of devotees

column1: Bhaktapur (Bhadgaon) Bhaktapur lies 16 km (10 miles) east of the center of Kathmandu. [SEP] Bhaktapur means “City of Devotees,” and this could today be taken to mean devotion to the old ways, for Bhaktapur is even more medieval than Old Kathmandu or Patan. [SEP] Exploring its narrow streets, you’ll
column3: upon squares filled with pottery drying in the sun and potters working at their hand-spun wheels, weavers at their looms, and wood-carvers at work on window frames. [SEP] Artists with the finest of brushes paint the minutely detailed religious paintings called thangkas. [SEP] These are widely sold, but the best

column1: From Kathmandu, short trips to the valley rim make it possible for those with limited time to see the high mountains at sunrise or sunset. [SEP] Nagarkot, which stands on the crest of a ridge at 2,195 m (7,200 ft), is about an hour’s drive from Bhaktapur and one of the best places in the Kathmandu area for viewing the Himalayas. [SEP] From this aerie on the rim of the Kathmandu Valley, 322 km (200 miles) of the Himalayas stretch out before you in an immense wall of rock and ice. [SEP] Although there are excellent views from the many lodges and hotels here, the view is even better from a nearby observation tower, which can be reached in about an hour’s walk from Nagarkot. [SEP] From this observation tower, it is possible to see as far as Mount Everest. [SEP] Most visitors
column3: for the sunrise or sunset on the mountains, and though the weather is often at its clearest in the early morning, low clouds and fog often obstruct the view. [SEP] The Kathmandu area’s other popular mountain-viewing spot is the village of Dhulikhel, which has a view very similar to that from Nagarkot and is a bit easier to reach, since it is on the main highway to Tibet. [SEP] This highway passes through Banepa, where you can turn off to visit Panauti. [SEP] The buildings here have great artistic and historic importance and for this reason have be

column1: The best way to see the wildlife, and certainly the most fun, is swaying atop a silently padding elephant. [SEP] The elephant grass along the several rivers in the park is so tall that only from an elephant’s back can you spot rhinos, deer, and other creatures, most of which are used to seeing elephants and do not run from them. [SEP] With luck, you’ll see a leopard draped indolently on a tree branch, and perhaps a stately sambar stag. [SEP] In winter, the gaur, the world’s largest wild ox, almost 2 m (6 ft) high at the shoulder,
column3: s out of its hideaway in the Siwalik Hills on the park’s southern edge in search of young grass. [SEP] Spotted deer, sloth bear, giant flying squirrels, and civet cats are among the other mammals the visitor may see. [SEP] There are several jungle lodges and tented camps within the park’s boundaries, and from any of these camps there is a very high likelihood that you will see rhinos and deer. [SEP] Tigers, leopards, and sloth bears are a bit more elusive. [SEP] All of these lodges, and even some outside the park, have their own elephants and nature guides. [SEP] On a stay at one of these lodges, a half day is usually spent in dug-out canoes searching for endangered gharials, a narrow jawed fish-eating crocodile, and their flesh-eating cousins, the huge marsh muggers. [SEP] However, these c

column1: EP] This well-watered farming zone stretches the length of the country on its southern border with India. [SEP] It’s only about 40 km (25 miles) wide, but a third of Nepal’s population lives here, producing much of the nation’s food. [SEP] A visit to Lumbini, birthplace of Gautama Buddha, can also be made in about three hours from Chitwan. [SEP] (There are also flights from Kathmandu to Bhairawa, the nearest airfield, with a bus service to Lumbini.) [SEP] The story goes that Buddha’s mother gave birth to him under a tree in a garden at Lumbini, unable to get back in time to the palace, some 20 km (12 miles) away. [SEP] Marking the spot is a pillar commemorating the visit in 250 b.c. of the Indian emperor Ashoka, a zealous convert to Buddhism. [SEP] Buddhist pilgrims from all over the world
column3: to Lumbini, and in recent years the site has been developed into an international cultural and religious park with several hotels and numerous Buddhist temples built by the world’s various Buddhist countries. [SEP] Although few tourists stray from the Kathmandu-Pokhara-Chitwan focal points, it is possible to see something of the undeveloped west without walking three weeks to get there. [SEP] There are now several lodges at Royal Bardia National Park on the Karnali River. [SEP] This park was created specifically as a preserve for tigers, which, with a little luck, can be seen here more easily than at Chitwan National Park. [SEP] Elephant rides, jungle walks and drives, river rafting, and bird-watching keep visitors busy. [SEP] The Karnali gorge above Chisopani is especially beautiful and is

column1: The Treaty of Fontainebleau in 1762 brought a shattering blow to the population of Louisiana. [SEP] Overnight, it appeared, they had been handed over to King Charles III of Spain — though the treaty was not announced until 1764. [SEP] It all made perfect sense to King Louis XV, cousin of Charles (both were Bourbons), for the French and Indian War, known in Europe as the Seven Years War, had been disastrous for French interests abroad. [SEP] Britain won Canada and everything east of the Mississippi, including Spanish Florida. [SEP] To Louis, Louisiana was now isolated in a British-ruled part of the world, a money-losing outpost that seemed to have no future. [SEP] It must have
column3: as an almost unbearable shock to the patriotic Frenchmen of New Orleans to be told that they were Spanish citizens. [SEP] Waiting for the first Spanish governor to arrive put a huge strain on the disillusioned society. [SEP] When Governor Antonio de Ulloa finally sailed up the Mississippi in 1766, four years after the treaty was signed, a crashing storm erupted, as if an omen for the climate ahead. [SEP] The governor, a scholarly retired naval officer with good intentions, was accompanied by a contingent of 80 Spanish soldiers, most of retirement age. [SEP] The high-society frolics of the Vaudreuil era were over; the Spanish governor’s wife froze out the Creole ladies of New Orleans from official invitation lists. [SEP] French-speaking citizens protested the snub with a petition and a demon

column1: The cinema is a great national passion, with over 300 different films showing in Paris every week. [SEP] For undubbed versions with French subtitles, look out for the letters VO (version originale) in listings or posters. [SEP] Cinemas on the Champs-Elysées, in Montparnasse, St-Germain-des-Prés, Bastille, and the Forum des Halles all show VO movies. [SEP] Keeping up with the latest in discos and clubs can be a full-time job for professional night-owls: there’s no point in turning up before midnight. [SEP] Many are nominally private, which means you only get in if the doormen like the way you look. [SEP] Some expensive, exclusive examples hide out around the Champs-Elysées, such as Régine’s in the rue de Ponthieu. [SEP] Louder, less expensive, younger, and weirder places
column3: and go around Bastille and Oberkampf. [SEP] There’s still some life in St-Germain-des-Prés and the Latin Quarter, especially in university term time — making local friends is the best way to find it. [SEP] Pop and rock concerts are held at the spectacular Zénith in the Parc de la Villette (métro: Porte de Pantin), at Parc-des-Princes (métro: Porte de St-Cloud), and also the Palais Omnisport de Bercy (métro: Bercy). [SEP] Ticket offices (billeteries) at FNAC or Virgin Megastore, both on the Champs-Elysées, will show what groups are in town.

column1: The French take their jazz seriously, and Paris has many jazz clubs. [SEP] Hot Brass (La Villette) and The New Morning (rue des Petites-Ecuries) attract big American and European musicians, while Le Dunois (rue Dunois) is an intimate place, cultivating more avant-garde music. [SEP] The Lionel Hampton club at the Méridien Etoile (Porte Maillot) has a full program of guest performers. [SEP] The old-established Caveau de la Huchette (rue de la Huchette in St-Germain-des-Prés) opens every night at 9:30pm for listening and dancing to a small combo or big band swing or bebop. [SEP] Entrance prices of around 60–120F may include your first drink; extra drinks cost 30–60F. [SEP] In the realm of classical music, Paris has
column3: back into its own, with many fine concerts at Salle Pleyel and Théâtre des Champs-Elysées, opera at the new Opéra-Bastille, and the ballet at the Opéra-Garnier. [SEP] In all cases, some seats are reasonably priced, though they tend to go quickly. [SEP] Look out for free concerts in churches. [SEP] Modern dance is enjoying a revival, with a new wave of small, imaginative companies beginning modestly enough at the Café de la Danse (passage Louis-Philippe) and Théâtre Garnier before reaching the heights of the Théâtre de la Bastille.

column1: . [SEP] Cistercian monks protested that such a sumptuous structure was an insult to the godly virtue of poverty, and today, architectural purists still find Notre-Dame a bit “too much.” [SEP] It was, however, built to inspire awe. [SEP] Over its long history, the cathedral has witnessed many momentous occasions. [SEP] In 1239, there was the procession of Louis IX, barefoot, carrying his holy treasure, Jesus’s Crown of Thorns (now in the Sainte-Chapelle); in 1430, it saw the humiliation of Henry VI of England (he was crowned King of France here; see page 15). [SEP] And in 1594, it was where Henri IV made his cynical conversion to Catholicism, a move that reinforced his hold on the French throne. [SEP] Napoléon chose it as the setting for crowning himself emperor (upstaging the Pope, who had
column3: to Paris expecting to do it). [SEP] In modern times, it has been a place for celebrating victory and mourning the passing of France’s leaders. [SEP] General de Gaulle marked the 1944 Liberation of Paris with a mass here, and in 1970 his death was similarly commemorated. [SEP] In 1996, a funeral service was held for de Gaulle’s archrival François Mitterrand here.

column1: oyal, Les Halles was for centuries the site of the capital’s central food markets (now in a more spacious, if less colorful, location at Rungis, near Orly). [SEP] To widespread regret, Victor Baltard’s great cast-iron and glass pavilions were torn down in the 1970s. [SEP] Eventually, gardens, children’s playgrounds, and the maze-like, partly below-ground shopping mall, Forum des Halles, transformed the site. [SEP] Saturdays bring throngs of teenagers from the suburbs to shop, watch films, roller skate, munch fast food, and just hang out. [SEP] The liveliest meeting place is around the monumental Renaissance Fontaine des Innocents (once part of a cemetery). [SEP] Bars, restaurants, and late-night brasseries line the adjoining rue Berger and the streets leading off it. [SEP] Clubs and discos
column3: alive at midnight and stay open to dawn, especially on weekends. [SEP] Away from the gardens and playgrounds, the quarter has its seedy side: drink and drugs, pickpockets and prostitutes. [SEP] Rue St-Denis, once primarily a red-light district, is now pedestrianized, but still has its share of sex shops. [SEP] The remarkable church of St-Eustache dominates the north side of Les Halles. [SEP] Built from 1532 to 1637, the main structure is late Gothic with a somewhat incongruous but imposing Renaissance colonnade on its western façade. [SEP] The church is renowned for its choral concerts and recitals on the grand organ designed by Baltard, architect of Les Halles.

column1: f modern construction. [SEP] It provides a remarkably authentic record of the development of the city, from the reign of Henri IV at the end of the 16th century to the advent of the Revolution. [SEP] Built on reclaimed marshland, as its name suggests, the Marais contains some of Europe’s most elegant Renaissance mansions (hôtels), many of which now serve as museums and libraries. [SEP] The one major change is the recent influx of trendy boutiques. [SEP] Take the métro to Rambuteau and start at the corner of the rue des Archives and the rue des Francs-Bourgeois, named after the poor (not bourgeois at all) allowed to live here tax-free in the 14th century. [SEP] The national archives are stored in an 18th-century mansion, Hôtel de Soubise. [SEP] Across a vast, horseshoe-shaped courtyard, you
column3: across the exquisite Rococo style of Louis XV’s time in the apartments of the Prince and Princess of Soubise. [SEP] Up on the first floor is the Musée de l’Histoire de France, with gems such as the only known portrait of Joan of Arc painted in her lifetime and the diary kept by Louis XVI. [SEP] His entry for 14 July 1789, the day the Bastille was stormed, reads Rien (Nothing). [SEP] A garden (not always open to the public) connects the Hôtel de Soubise with its twin, Hôtel de Rohan, on the rue Vieille du Temple. [SEP] Look out for Robert le Lorrain’s fine Les Chevaux d’Apollon over the old stables in the second courtyard, admired as one of France’s most beautiful 18th-century sculptures.

column1: Musée du Louvre Revamping the Musée du Louvre since the 1980s has made this formidable palace of art far more accessible, in all senses. [SEP] In 1793, when the leaders of the Revolution declared the palace a national museum, the Louvre held 630 works of art; a recent inventory listed 250,000. [SEP] Don’t be put off — it’s an exhilarating experience just attempting to
column3: to grips with such vast collections of painting, sculpture, and artifacts from 5000 b.c. to 1848 (from which date the Musée d’Orsay’s French collections continue the story to 1914). [SEP] The magnificent glass Pyramid designed by American architect I. M. Pei has gained acceptance as a harmonious entrance to this most venerable of French museums. [SEP] An escalator descends to the reception area, which comprises shops, cafés, and the ticket office. [SEP] At the information counter, collect a copy of the free handbook with color-coded floor plans. [SEP] (Admission, too, is free on the first Sunday of every month.)

column1: saw a series of miraculous visions of the Virgin Mary — said to disclose three secrets, or prophecies, to the children — followed by a solar phenomenon witnessed by thousands in October of the same year. [SEP] (Two of the children died of pneumonia soon after these inexplicable events; the third, Lucia, now in her 90s, has been a cloistered Carmelite nun in Coimbra since 1929 and makes very few public appearances.) [SEP] The 20th-century neo-Baroque basilica that draws so many of the faithful, said to be twice as big as St. Peter’s in Rome, faces an immense but rather plain square. [SEP] Pilgrimages are held on the 13th of every month, with the most important observances on that date in May and October. [SEP] Yet even on an ordinary weekday, scattered believers, some kneeling in penitence,
column3: to Fátima to pay homage to the Virgin Mary. [SEP] Tomar

column1: ctions. [SEP] About 16 km (10 miles) west of Faro, a simple white church stands out on a small hill overlooking the thundering highway. [SEP] A sign simply says “S. Lourenço” — indicating the turn-off to São Lourenço do Matto (Church of St. Lawrence of the Woods). [SEP] Inside is one of the most extraordinary displays of azulejo design you’ll ever see. [SEP] Every square inch of the Baroque, 15th-century church — its walls, vaulted ceiling, and cupola — is covered with hand-painted, blue-and-white ceramic tiles. [SEP] Most date from the early 18th century and depict biblical scenes detailing the life of St. Lawrence. [SEP] The ensemble is a stunning sight, not to be missed. [SEP] Loulé, north of Almancil, is a prosperous town known for its leather, lace, and copper goods. [SEP] Tour groups
column3: from far and wide to shop at the colorful, bustling market. [SEP] Just below the permanent market halls on the main Praça da República, you’ll find a well-preserved section of the medieval castle walls (which were much damaged by the 1755 earthquake). [SEP] Also worth visiting are the Igreja Matriz (São Clemente), a 13th-century Gothic church with 18th-century azulejo tiles; the Convento da Graça, with a terrific Manueline portal; and Ermida de Nossa Senhora da Conceição, a small church prized for its Baroque altar and ceramic tiles. [SEP] In the streets directly below the castle walls, you may well hear the sounds of craftsmen beating copper — from whom you can buy direct. [SEP] If you are in the Algarve in springtime, don’t miss the Loulé Carnival. [SEP] The parades, “Battle of Flowers,”

column1: The Sotavento Coast Heading east from the provincial capital of Faro, the first settlement of any size you will
column3: to is the colorful fishing town of Olhão. [SEP] Olhão used to be described as the “little white Cubist town of the Algarve,” its architecture likened to that of North African towns. [SEP] The parish church (which also goes by the name of Nossa Senhora do Rosário) was founded by King Dom Pedro II in 1698. [SEP] The small chapel at the rear, Nossa Senhora dos Aflitos (Our Lady of the Afflicted), is where women often pray when their fishermen husbands are away at sea. [SEP] Instead of the red-tiled roofs and filigreed chimneys seen elsewhere in the Algarve, the Olhão skyline comprises flat-topped roofs of terraces called açoeitas. [SEP] The Olhão fish market is one of the Algarve’s best, especially famous for its mussels and other shellfish.

column1: re chafing under the yoke of colonial rule and the bitter system of slavery. [SEP] To squash subversive ideas about independence in Puerto Rico, Madrid imposed ruthless military control. [SEP] The most memorable incident occurred in 1868 in the mountain town of Lares, when government forces crushed an uprising of secessionists, killing or jailing the insurgents, and many innocent victims. [SEP] The event is remembered as El Grito de Lares (the cry of Lares). [SEP] The colonial government could not, however, hold back the tide of change sweeping the Caribbean. [SEP] In 1872, one momentous decree abolished the 350-year-old institution of slavery in Puerto Rico, and in 1897 Spain cut the colonial ties and finally granted the island autonomy. [SEP] The long dream of independence seemed to have
column3: true. [SEP] But eight months after Madrid had authorized home rule for Puerto Rico, American troops arrived to take it away. [SEP] The Spanish-American War was no great challenge for the US force that landed at Guánica, on Puerto Rico’s calm south coast, rather than at fortified San Juan. [SEP] Military resistance was spotty at best. [SEP] By starting at the soft underbelly, the 16,000 troops of General Nelson A. Miles gained control of the island in less than three weeks. [SEP] The central issue that had drawn Spain and the United States into war — Cuba’s struggle for independence — was resolved in that island’s favor: Cuba’s freedom was guaranteed by the Paris Treaty of 1898. [SEP] But Spain’s two other major colonies, the Philippines and Puerto Rico, simply changed hands, becoming coloni

column1: Guayaberas. [SEP] The best-dressed Puerto Rican gentlemen wear these tailored, embroidered shirts for many occasions. [SEP] Hammocks. [SEP] The old Indian industry is still alive here. [SEP] Hammocks
column3: in a remarkable variety of styles, colors, and sizes (a miniature model for your cat, a double-wide hammock for the adventurous). [SEP] Imported goods. [SEP] Window-shopping reveals surprises galore: Swiss watches, Indian saris, Balinese sarongs, German crystal, and more.

column1: Opposite the entrance to the Barracks is the long white building that houses the Institute of Puerto Rican Culture. [SEP] A new museum is planned for this space, but in the meantime temporary art exhibitions display the best of Puerto Rican painting and sculpture. [SEP] Follow Calle Beneficencia, the street leading off the right side of the barracks, back towards town. [SEP] You’ll soon
column3: to a small square on your left with a huge totemic sculpture. [SEP] This is Plaza del Quinto Centenario (Quincentenary Square). [SEP] The sculpture symbolizes the 500 years of Puerto Rico’s existence. [SEP] On close inspection, Amerindian and Spanish themes can be seen, but some elements are a little obscure. [SEP] One specimen is said to be over 2,500 years old; some trees are so wide it takes several people to reach around them; others soar hundreds of feet into the air. [SEP] The forest gets over 180 inches (41���2 m) of rain each year — that’s some 100 billion gallons (450 billion liters) of water. [SEP] The animals that live here are also amazing. [SEP] This is one of the last habitats of the threatened Puerto Rican parrot. [SEP] The infamous coquí (see page 47)is, of course, heard everywhere. [SEP] All in all, the park in an impressive sight, with slope after slope of vegetation laced with mountain streams and beautiful waterfalls and mountain peaks extend away into the distance. column3: right to the El Portal Tropical Forest Center at the entrance to the park. [SEP] This facility presents important information about the history of the park, its plant and animal species, and its role in the local ecology. [SEP] You can then travel on higher into the park, toward the summit. [SEP] You can’t drive the whole 8 miles (13 km) between the visitors center and the end of the road, but there are several car parks and rest areas on the way, so there’s ample access. [SEP] Two popular stops are La Coca Falls, on the right after the 5-mile (8-km) point, and the Yokahú Observation Tower, at the 51⁄2-mile (9-km) point. column1: Culebra, much smaller at 21 sq miles (34 sq km), is north of Vieques. [SEP] It is the largest rock in a collection of over twenty that attract sailors and divers from the main island. [SEP] Culebra was known as the Spanish Virgin Island until the American takeover — it lies halfway between Puerto Rico and St. Thomas in the US Virgin Islands. [SEP] Its only town is named Dewey, after Admiral George Dewey, a hero of the American-Spanish War of 1898. [SEP] The local people are more apt to call it Pueblo. [SEP] Culebra is full of natural beauty: beaches (Flamenco is the most celebrated), clear waters full of marine life, and land awash with flowers. [SEP] Most people
column3: just to sit on the beach or walk in the fresh air. [SEP] Much of the island is now managed by the US Fish and Wildlife Service, to preserve the environment. [SEP] It makes an interesting day trip from Puerto Rico and a total contrast to hot days in the streets of Old San Juan. [SEP] The Southeast

column1: Puerto Rico’s second city, Ponce is as much steeped in history as Old San Juan. [SEP] Founded in 1692, it was named after a relative of Juan Ponce de León, not the famous explorer himself. [SEP] Ponce is a thriving port city, very modern in many ways, but it lives up to its name of “Pearl of the South.” [SEP] At the very heart of the city is a jewel of an old town, well-preserved thanks to a massive and expensive restoration program begun in the 1980s. [SEP] Hundreds of careworn buildings were brought back to life, and power cables were buried underground and out of sight. [SEP] Along with this physical transformation came a cultural change: Ponce has be
column3: a focus for social events that celebrate Puerto Rican history and tradition; several major festivals are held here throughout the year. [SEP] The focus of the city is Parque Degetau in Plaza Las Delicias (Delight Square), known by most locals as Plaza de Ponce. [SEP] Most of what you want to see is within a few minutes’ walk of this plaza, and cafés and restaurants for refreshments are also near at hand. [SEP] You can spend a wonderful morning just soaking in the atmosphere. [SEP] The park, with its shady trees, cooling fountains, and somber bronze statues, including one of Luis Muñoz Marín, is where people

column1: p to 7 ft (2 m) long — congregate here because they’ve learned they’ll be well supplied with tasty tidbits offered by the humans on shore. [SEP] North of Ponce are attractions of a different kind. [SEP] Take Route 503 out of town — this road runs along the banks of the Río Portuguéz — and after about a mile and a half (2 km) you’ll arrive at the Tibes Indian Ceremonial Park, one of the most important Amerindian archaeological sites in the Caribbean. [SEP] The ceremonial site and cemetery are across the river, and you may not enter without a guide. [SEP] A small museum explains the known history of the Amerindian races; it has a number of cabinets holding artifacts, as well as a skeleton, still in the traditional fetal burial position. [SEP] Once you’re into the park, the ceremonial grounds
column3: into view. [SEP] Open spaces discovered since the 1960s are now believed to be used for “ball games,” which had an important though as yet only poorly understood ceremonial purpose in Indian culture. [SEP] High in the hills behind Ponce is Hacienda Buena Vista. [SEP] To get there, take Route 10, a major north-south artery. [SEP] The road climbs steeply into dense vegetation and cooler air before you see signs for the hacienda; the climate and environmental conditions here were ideal for the coffee that the plantation began to grow more than 150 years ago. [SEP] The plantation fell into neglect in the 20th century, but since 1984 it has been returned to its original state by The Conservation Trust of Puerto Rico. column1: Mexico’s folkloric traditions have be
column3: the centerpiece of the modern “Mexican Fiesta,” created especially with the tourist in mind. [SEP] These full evenings of entertainment generally include a makeshift marketplace featuring artesanía for sale, a buffet Mexican dinner, games (involving drinking large quantities of tequila), mariachi music, a presentation of folkloric dance from around the country, and a generous supply of margaritas and other beverages. [SEP] Most of the time these are smallish presentations, with dances performed by amateur groups; at their worst, they can be truly gaudy and almost laughable shows. [SEP] The exception is in Acapulco. [SEP] The Centro de Convenciones offers arguably the best Fiesta Mexicana in the country, and is the closest you’ll

[SEP] The majority of clubs, and the ubiquitous Carlos ‘n’ Charlie’s, are located along the main boulevard, Miguel de la Madrid. [SEP] In Ixtapa, sunset happy hours offer the most options, and Mexican fiestas seem to be a “best bet” for a complete evening. [SEP] Other later night offerings are a sampling of what you’ll find in any resort town in Mexico: Christine’s disco at the Krystal Hotel, Sr. [SEP] Frogs, and Carlos ‘n’ Charlie’s. [SEP] The only really original option here is the club, La Valentina, a combination restaurant/video bar with a desert-inspired décor. [SEP] There is no doubt that Acapulco rules when it

[SEP] The tour includes a visit to a secluded beach and a detailed explanation of the flora and fauna of the area. [SEP] Lovers of speed and thrill-seekers will enjoy the fast-paced tour along the Papagayo River, 72 km (48 miles) north of Acapulco. [SEP] Shotover-Jet (Tel. [SEP] This perpendicular meeting of streets contains something for every taste and budget, in both dining and nightlife. [SEP] Immediately south of Viejo Vallarta is the fashionable residential neighborhood of Conchas Chinas, with numerous villas for rent, and a few hotels set into the cliffside. [SEP] Extending from Conchas Chinas along the South Shore, the landscape changes to dramatic mountains that tumble toward the sea. [SEP] Tucked into the private coves of this coast, you’ll find a collection of full-service hotels made to order for honeymoons and romantic escapes. [SEP] At the end of this stretch of shore, you’ll
column3: to Mismaloya Bay, where you can still climb up the ridge to the ruins of the set built for the Night of the Iguana. [SEP] Day Trips from Puerto Vallarta

column1: Though Acapulco is, admittedly, past its prime, there are still plenty of reasons to visit and numerous ways to enjoy the famously sunny days there. [SEP] Acapulco remains Mexico’s most traditional resort for those looking for a beach, yet also want to feel as if they’ve been to Mexico. [SEP] Where other resorts in Mexico have been accused of being homogenized to meet the tastes of North American travelers, Acapulco remains true to her essence, from the cacophony of families filling colorful, public sands, to the classically late nights in glitzy clubs. [SEP] And Acapulco has one thing that no other place has — the absolutely stunning view of Acapulco Bay, which, day or night, is an image as memorable as any you’ll
column3: across in your travels. [SEP] Acapulco is more of a city than other Pacific coastal destinations, with high-rise hotels lined up like dominoes around the edge of the bay. [SEP] It offers more options for dining, shopping, and other activities than anywhere else along Mexico’s western shoreline; many are geared for families.
